story: Speaking to Labour Leave, the crossbench peer argued it was time the Labour Party got off the fence and admitted it supports the Brexit referendum result.&nbspLord Owen warned Labour MPs in the north-east of England would pay a very severe price at the next election if Jeremy Corbyn tried to thwart Britons' decision to leave the EU.He said: &ldquoJust get off the fence.&ldquoWe all know that Jeremy Corbyn wants to leave, we know that his Chancellor wants to leave, we know that the group that is now in control of their party basically wants to leave.                German diplomat claims Brexit has no role as EU market more important&ldquoStop trying to pretend to the electorate that you are on the side of those who want to remain and you&rsquore on the side of those who want to leave.&ldquoYou can&rsquot get away with it.&ldquoAnd if they were to adversely say that we should stay and bath the referendum, the price that Labour MPs in the north east of England and many other parts of the country outside London will pay will be very, very severe.&ldquoSo it&rsquos a phoney war that is going on in the House of Commons, it does them no good and it does us no good.Lord Owen added crossbench MPs should get together in the battle for the new proposal of temporary membership of the EEA for Britain during the two years transition period.&nbspBrexit new: Lord Owen calls on Jeremy Corbyn to admit he wants to Leave the EU  (Image: LABOUR LEAVE&bull)The crossbench peer claimed the proposal would only need the support&nbspof 40 to 50 MPs in Parliament to push away the idea of a Chequers agreement with Brussels.He said: &ldquoAnd I want now a few crossbench MPs to get together and support the EEA entry for the transition period.&ldquoI think they&rsquore very close to doing it and I think once they manage to do it they will show they have enough support, maybe only 40 or 50 will put their name to it but that&rsquos enough support to kill the idea of going alone and kill off the idea of a Chequers agreement.&ldquoBecause neither are serious options for any sensible politicians to take.Former Labour, now independent, MP Frank Field claimed Labour MPs could back a Norway-style transition deal post-Brexit to allow time to develop a wide-ranging trade deal after the UK leaves the bloc.Eurosceptic Mr Field, who quit the Labour whip earlier this year, said if the Government fails to negotiate a suitable Brexit deal in time then there are merits of the UK joining the European Economic Area, the European Free Trade Association court and customs union.&nbspHe said a &ldquono deal Brexit would unravel with its threat to jobs and livelihoods.&nbsp&nbspThe idea of such a trade deal was first suggested by Tory MP Nick Boles, which was later backed by William Hague, the former foreign secretary, and Nicky Morgan, the former education secretary.&nbspCritics have pushed back against a Norway-style deal certain it would still involve a backstop in the withdrawal agreement to prevent a hard border with Northern Ireland.&nbsp

title: budget 2018 news summary reaction labour party john mcdonnell
story: News host Colin Brazier made a subtle dig at Labour Shadow Secretary Rebecca Long-Bailey while discussing the Budget earlier today.Speaking on whether Labour would &ldquounpick or support Tory promises on tax allowance, the Labour MP declared: &ldquoWhat John McDonnell said was very clear this morning, that in the context of this Budget we wouldn&rsquot unpick them because there is little else offered to many working people across the board.Mr Brazier then interjected: &ldquoAndy Burnham seems less certain doesn&rsquot he.Ms Long-Bailey then dodged the comment and continued: &ldquoWell those on lower incomes seem to be hammered by this Budget.                Susanna Reid MOCKS Jeremy Corbyn's AWKWARD attempts to 'floss'                McDonnell risks furious backlash as he makes SHOCK admission to BBC&ldquoIf you look at the Universal Credit promises that were made yesterday, they&rsquoll go nowhere near the scale of cuts that are being encapsulated within the Universal Credit rollout.&ldquoSo to offer reductions in the threshold, as Philip Hammond stated, it&rsquos not going to improve people&rsquos living experience dramatically by any stretch of the imagination, and we wanted to see a lot more action.John McDonnell shockingly confessed Labour&rsquos support for the income tax cuts announced by his Tory counterpart yesterday.The Labour Shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer told BBC&rsquos Today Programme: &ldquoWe&rsquoll support the tax cuts at the moment on the basis that it will inject some demand into the economy.Budget 2018: the news host made a subtle dig at contradictions within the Labour Party (Image: Sky News )John McDonnell admitted Labour&rsquos support for the cuts after radio host Martha Kearney asked: &ldquoNow you want to be in power as soon a possible and who knows, looking at this budget there could even be a snap election.&ldquoSo let&rsquos assume there is a Labour Government, would you reverse the tax cuts being planned?He also admitted Labour would keep in place the Tory changes to the personal allowance.Mr McDonnell said: &ldquoWe&rsquoll leave those personal allowances at whatever we inherit, but our focus will be on a fair taxation system.Labour Mayor of Manchester Andy Burnham tweeted in response: &ldquoAt a loss to understand why we are doing this.Mr McDonnell&rsquos comments also seem to contradict that of Labour MP Emily Thornberry, who criticised the Tory Party over &ldquotax cuts for the rich.She tweeted yesterday: &ldquoThere we are - tax cuts for the rich and they are coming earlier. #Budget2018.The Labour Press team tweeted yesterday: We were never all in it together. Austerity was a political choice, not an economic necessity. Meanwhile, the Tories have continued to hand tax cuts to the very wealthiest in our society.In a Budget signalling a major shift in the Government&rsquos priorities, Chancellor Philip Hammond declared the tax burden on hard-working households could be eased rather than raised.Mr Hammond told the Commons: I can report to the British people that their hard work is paying off and the era of austerity finally coming to an end.

title: Brexit news UK EU Budget 2018 Theresa May European Union Philip Hammond
story: Philip Hammond warned at the weekend that a fresh Budget would be needed should the UK leave the European Union without a Brexit deal.Downing Street interjected claiming the Budget would go ahead regardless of what type of Brexit deal the UK secures with the EU.The Chancellor has now claimed that his Budget was based on the assumption of an &ldquoaverage-type free trade deal being agreed, insisting that a Brexit agreement with the EU would result in a &ldquodeal idend for the economy.Commenting on Philip Hammond's remarks of whether a Brexit no deal would be a &ldquoshock to the economy, Mr Duncan Smith said: &ldquoI think he said, and I remember listening to him this morning, he said that ultimately is that it could be.                Merkel is a 'liability' who is unlikely to finish term as Chancellor                Peer calls on Jeremy Corbyn to 'stop pretending' he backs Remain&ldquoThe reality, he also went on to say, it quite often, more often than not, the kind of shocks that happen are ones you don&rsquot foresee.&ldquoIt is wholly possible that the UK economy will do very well. I am one of those that believes whatever the circumstances, we will do well because the UK economy, as I think the chief economist of Deutsche Bank said, a German, he said the UK will thrive outside of the EU.&ldquoI think that is the key element. And I see a poll today that 52 percent of the public also think the same.&ldquoWe are at the point where nobody wants to hear any more forecasts, any more threats, any more promises. They just want to know, get this done, and get us out.Brexit news: Iain Duncan Smith insisted that Brits just want to get on with Brexit (Image: BBC&bull)Commenting on the Budget, and whether a Brexit agreement with the European Union would result in a &ldquodeal idend for the economy,&nbspMr&nbspDuncan Smith added: &ldquoI thought he toned the rhetoric right down, from where we half-expected it to be three days before.&ldquoI think he decided that we were heading towards the end of March when the whole issue about what we have, what deal, what arrangement we have, where will we be going will become clearer.&ldquoHe has allowed the possibility for change at that point, which is reasonable, I think even this morning back on the BBC he was saying &lsquolook we don&rsquot know for certain what will happen&rsquo and he was being a lot more cautious about it and I think that is the right place to be.&ldquoIf it was intended to lean on people to get them to vote for anything that comes back, it certainly went over their heads and I don&rsquot think anyone registered it.Mr&nbspHammond said &ldquothe era of austerity is finally coming to an end during the 2018 Budget in the House of Commons on Monday.During his speech, the Chancellor promised a &ldquobrighter future for &ldquothe strivers, the grafters and the carers.Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn rejected the Chancellor&rsquos pledge that austerity was coming to an end.

title: uk weather forecast storms latest met office october hurricane oscar
story: Three brutal cyclonic systems are lined up to brutalise at the UK through the coming days sparking warnings to hunker down for a ferocious spell of weather.Storm Adrian, currently tearing through the Continent, will take a swipe at the UK on Tuesday before a more powerful storm and an ex-hurricane join forces for a weekend assault.Hurricane Oscar is on course to charge across the Atlantic and towards the UK at the same time a separate low-pressure system hits on Friday night.If it arrives alone this low could give rise to the next named storm of the season, Deirdre, however it may link up with the Atlantic hurricane to form megastorm Oscar.                BBC Weather: Storm Oscar to STRIKE UK bringing DRAMATIC changes                 BBC Weather: 'Damaging' storm looms as temperatures PLUNGE this weekBritain&rsquos weather will turn deeply volatile from around mid-week with swathes of the country facing gales and heavy rain, forecasters warn.Much of the country will enjoy a cold but calm day tomorrow although south-eastern England will take a hammering from French-named Storm Adrian.Met Office meteorologist Bonnie Diamond said: &ldquoTuesday will be largely dry and settled although it is going to be another cold day.&ldquoThe only exception will be the southeast which will see the effects from Storm Adrian which has been named by the French meteorological service.&ldquoThere will be a risk of strong winds and heavy rain as this area of low pressure moves up from the Continent and clips south-eastern Britain.&ldquoWe are expecting organised bands of rain and some strong winds which could touch gale-force.UK weather forecast: A megastorm trio is set to batter Britain (Image: WX CHARTS)Wider parts of the country will turn stormy from Wednesday meaning trick or treaters face a wet and windy Halloween.Britain will be put through the wringer again on Thursday before storms sweep in from the Atlantic ahead of the weekend, Miss Diamond added.Depending on the track and intensity of one low-pressure system, Britain could be in the firing line for the fourth named storm of the season - Deirdre, she warned.She said: &ldquoThere is an area of low pressure coming in off the Atlantic later on Friday bringing some very strong winds and heavy rain widely across the country.&ldquoThere is some uncertainty at the moment as to whether this will be affected by the remains of Hurricane Oscar which is currently in the Atlantic.&ldquoIf the remnants are picked up by this low then the resulting storm will keep the name Oscar, if not, and the separate low affects the UK independently it will take up the name Deirdre.&ldquoThere is a lot of uncertainty around what will happen at the moment, as it depends on the track of theses systems.UK weather forecast: Hurricane Oscar is tracking east (Image: NOAA)UK weather forecast: Hurricane Oscar is ripping through the Atlantic with 85mph winds (Image: NOAA)&ldquoHowever what we can say at the moment is that we are looking at a very unsettled spell of weather from the end of the week and through the weekend&ldquoThe emphasis will be on the winds and we could see gales or severe gales in the worst affected regions, we will know more a bit later in the week.&ldquoFor many people across England and Wales Friday will be a decent day, the unsettled weather will start to affect the country later in the day and into the weekend.UK weather models show Storm Adrian sweeping up the east coast of the UK tomorrow afternoon whipping up gales along south-eastern coasts.The storm has put parts of France including the island of Corsica on red alert for damaging gales, rain and flooding.Alerts remain in place until tomorrow morning when the storm moves northwards into the English Channel and towards the UK.Charts reveal the next battering will be on Friday night when a more brutal region of low pressure sweeps in from the Atlantic.UK weather forecast: Storm Adrian is tearing through Europe (Image: WX CHARTS)UK weather forecast: A second storm Deirdre is due to sweep in on Saturday (Image: WX CHARTS)UK weather forecast: Gale-force winds are poised to strike (Image: MAGIC SEAWEED)The colossal storm threatens to whip up near-75mph winds around its centre putting swathes of the UK on alert for severe gales and torrential downpours.The churning vortex, potentially driven by the remains of Hurricane Oscar, will continue to hammer the country through Saturday and Sunday.The mammoth storm is currently hurtling north-eastwards across the Atlantic with windspeed of around 85 mph.Latest forecast charts from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) predict it will make a direct hit with the UK this weekend.A NOAA spokesman said: &ldquoOscar has slowed its forward motion significantly and has made a turn toward the west-northwest.&ldquoA turns toward the north and then toward the north-northeast are forecast on Tuesday as Oscar moves north of the ridge axis ahead of an eastward-moving deep-layer trough currently approaching Bermuda.&ldquoThe trough is expected to continue advancing eastward over the next couple of days, accelerating Oscar toward the northeast on Wednesday through Friday.&ldquoNone of the model guidance shows the hurricane being captured and instead keeps the cyclone as a separate entity that accelerates northeastward into the mid-latitude westerlies as a strong extratropical cyclone.WeatherOnline forecaster Garry Nicholson warned the nation is about to endure a very unsettled start to the final stretch of autumn.He said: &ldquoThe start of November is expected to become very unsettled as a strengthening jet stream brings powerful weather systems in from the south-west.&ldquoThe remnants of Hurricane Oscar currently over the mid-Atlantic are likely to move close to the British Isles by the weekend with a threat of stormy winds and heavy rain.

title: EU news Jean Claude Juncker clocks change daylight saving 2019 latest
story: Opposition grows for Jean-Claude Juncker plans to abolish EU clock changes in 2019 (Image: )Top eurocrat Jean-Claude Juncker&rsquos bid to abolish seasonal clock changes within the EU were branded unrealistic by transport ministers in the first sign of public descent for the plans.The European Commission President&rsquos signature policy, which is mainly backed by Germany, would have seen Europe stop changing its clocks in October 2019, creating a permanent summer or winter time.But a number of sceptical EU member states have criticised the proposed timeline, insisting the change will leave businesses and citizens unprepared for the huge policy shift.Austrian transport minister Norbert Hofer, who hosted his 27 EU counterparts in Graz, questioned whether Mr Juncker&rsquos rushed through policy would receive the support of a majority of member states.Mr Hofer said: &ldquoIf we aim to do this in 2019, as the European Commission suggested, this will not be supported by the majority of member states.He, instead, suggested Brussels&rsquo powerful executive hold off on their plans and look at the summer of 2021 for its potential implementation.Britain, Sweden and Poland are amongst the most vocal of the member states, who are currently opposed to Mr Juncker&rsquos plans.Mr Hofer said: &ldquoThree countries were sceptical and one was concerned that we could end up with a patchwork of different times zones.                UK could SCRAP clock change from 2019 in DRASTIC plan proposed by EU                EU pushes on with talks to scrap daylight saving timeAirlines were amongst the major businesses who had raised their own questions about abolishing the twice-yearly clock change.They would need more time to make necessary technical preparations, according to Mr Hofer.&ldquoFor example, the airline industry tells us they need at least 18 months to prepare, he said.Brexit was also mentioned as the possibility of a time border being created between Northern Ireland and Great Britain remains given the uncertainty surrounding negotiations on Britain&rsquos EU departure.&ldquoWe must also be careful that we don&rsquot end up with a patchwork of time zones, Mr Hofer added.Luxembourg&rsquos transport minister Fancois Bausch said it would be a &ldquocatastrophe for his country to be locked in a different timezone from Belgium, France and Germany.This is because half of Luxembourg&rsquos workforce commute into the country and require a harmonised system with its neighbours, according to Mr Bausch.Danish transport minister Ole Birk Olesen said his country would require a full public debate and therefore cannot comply with the 2019 timetable.He said: &ldquoThere is not much awareness about the fact that it will have costs whatever we choose.Last month, Mr Juncker announced the Commission would press on with its plans after an EU-wide poll found 84 percent of the 4.6 million participants supported abolishing the twice-yearly clock change.But the poll&rsquos results were somewhat skewed because they represented less than one percent of the EU&rsquos population and most respondents were from Germany.

story: The leader of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) announced yesterday that she would be standing down as Chancellor of Germany once her term ends in 2021.But one economist doubts that Mrs Merkel will be able to stick it out for another three years.Oliver Rakau, a&nbspchief German economist at Oxford Economics, was asked in an interview with CNBC how likely he thought it was that the Chancellor would stay until 2021.In response, he said: &ldquoPersonally, I do not think it&rsquos as likely as she&rsquos probably hoping.                Merkel could replace Juncker to 'COMPLETE German DOMINATION of Europe'&ldquoBut it&rsquos really the only thing she could say in the given circumstances.&ldquoMy personal baseline case is that once we know who her successor is as the head of the CDU, her party, it&rsquos likely that person will eventually take over as Chancellor - either in a new form coalition after new elections.But the cynic added that it doesn&rsquot look likely that there will be elections any time soon.He continued: &ldquoPersonally, I think there&rsquos not a big appetite in German politics for new elections at least right now because the two main parties, CUD as well as the Social Democrats, are polling very weakly.Merkel unlikely to stay to 2021 says economist (Image: Getty)&ldquoSo I think they will, for now, just try to limp on.Mrs Merkel&rsquos decision to resign came after disappointing election results in the west German state of Hesse, where the CDU suffered huge losses.Klaus-Peter Willsch, the CDU's representative in the state, said the result was a demonstration of how no one was satisfied with the current federal government.This is a true hint that it is not a state policy but a federal policy problem we are facing - everyone could see our government is not performing, he told CNBC.

story: French Conservative Senator Jean Bizet claimed Macron had to step-up but warned the new unofficial role would be &ldquovery difficult for Mr Macron.Mrs Merkel&rsquos decision to quit politics after her current term as Chancellor ends in 2021 sent shockwaves across Europe and the world yesterday.Sen Bizet said: &ldquoGermany has been the strongman of Europe for many years but today it has become the weak man, if I may say so.&ldquoEverything rests &ndash and will rest more and more &ndash on president Macron&rsquos shoulders. It will be very difficult for him.Emmanuel Macron is poised to take over from Angela Merkel as the leader of Europe (Image: Getty)Emmanuel Macron wants to be the strongman of Europe (Image: Getty)Mr Bizet, the chairman of the senate&rsquos committee for European affairs, told the TV channel Public S&eacutenat the German leader&rsquos decision to not seek a fifth term as chancellor was &ldquoa great disappointment but sadly an expected disappointment.He added: &ldquoIt&rsquos bad news for the coalition, bad news for Germany, bad news for France but also bad news for Europe.Mrs Merkel, 64, announced her decision to retire in 2021 and also step down as leader of the Christian Democrats (CDU) after her party on Sunday suffered its second regional election setback in as many weeks.The CDU and its Social Democrat coalition partners suffered heavy losses in the weekend&rsquos regional election in the large central state of Hesse, home to the financial capital Frankfurt. &nbsp                Dover MP fires warning to 'bully' Macron over Calais Brexit threat                Macron REFUSES to stop Saudi Arabia arms sales after Khashoggi murderBut stepping down as CDU chairman further undermines Mrs Merkel&rsquos authority, as she had previously said the party chair and chancellery should be held by the same person.While Mrs Merkel has dominated European politics since 2005, helping guide the Brussels bloc through the eurozone crisis, her decision in 2015 to open Germany&rsquos doors to more than one million migrants fleeing war in the Middle East caused deep isions within the EU and weakened her support.Mr Bizet said: &ldquoBig European issues cannot be solved alone. But in this case, Angela Merkel did not consult with her European partners before making a unilateral decision that completely upset the European Union&rsquos social balance.He added that mass immigration &ldquoweakens the single market.France news: Could Emmanuel Macron step into the vacuum left by Angela Merkel? (Image: )But while Mr Macron is thought to be plotting for France to take over from Germany as Europe&rsquos engine, he was effusive in his praise of Mrs Merkel when commenting on her looming retirement later on Monday.The 40-year-old centrist hailed his allies &ldquovery respectable and &ldquodignified decision to not run again after the end of her term, as he paid tribute to her ability to face financial and migrant crises in recent years without forgetting Europe&rsquos fundamental values.&ldquoShe leads her country with much courage, he told a news conference in Paris.

title: new book reveals audrey hepburn secret life
story: Actress Audrey Hepburn (Image: Henry GrisFPGGetty Images)In Dutch Girl: Audrey Hepburn And World War II, author Robert Matzen sheds light on the untold story of the late screen siren's wartime experiences in the Nazioccupied Netherlands. He said it features new interviews with people who knew her in the war, wartime diaries, and research in classified Dutch archives. Born Edda Kathleen Hepburn-Ruston in Brussels to a British father and Dutch mother, the Breakfast At Tiffany's star split her childhood between Belgium, England and the Netherlands. She was 10 when war broke out in 1939. A year later she was in Arnhem when the Germans invaded.                Audrey Hepburn's son: 'One day we will find a cure for the cancer...                Breakfast at Tiffany's script reveals THIS blonde bombshell was fir...She previously said: Had we known we were going to be occupied for five years, we might have all shot ourselves.The book, due out in April, also tells how the star, who died in 1993 aged 63, had to contend with her father being a Nazi agent and her mother a Nazi supporter as well as working as a doctor's assistant in the Battle of Arnhem in 1944.In a foreword to the book, Hepburn's son Luca Dotti, 48, said it had solved mysteries about her hidden past.He wrote: I now understand why she was open about certain facts and why she kept so many others in a secluded area of her being.

story: Oil tanks are seen at a Sinopec plant in Hefei, Anhui province (Image: Jianan Yu REUTERS)China National Petroleum Corp (CNPC) and China National Offshore Oil Corp (CNOOC) have expressed interest in bidding, officials from the self-ruling part of Denmark said.&nbspThe Arctic island is shifting its oil and gas licensing strategy from offshore to onshore in an effort to generate revenues faster, they said.The next blocks to be tendered will be on the Disko Island and Nuussuaq Peninsula area of West Greenland, industry and energy minister Aqqalu Jerimiassen told Reuters on the sidelines of a Greenland Day event at the Danish embassy in Beijing.Jerimiassen, who took office in May, said he met with the two Chinese oil majors, as well as China's National Energy Administration, on Monday.                OIL NEWS: India to OVERTAKE China as global oil driver                 REVEALED: Iran's PLOT to use FRAUDThe Chinese asked for follow-up meetings to discuss technical issues, said Jorn Skov Nielsen, Jerimiassen's deputy.They have not been active in Greenland earlier. It's a new approach, he added. We are moving the short-term strategy of licensing onshore.CNPC and CNOOC did not immediately respond to a request for comment. In neighbouring Iceland, CNOOC has been exploring the offshore Dreki area but has not reported any finds.Nielsen said it was too early to say how many blocks would be tendered, or to give an estimate for the resources in the highly prospective area.Oil drilling rig platform (Image: SCOTT HEPPELLAFPGetty Images)The U.S. Geogological Survey puts Greenland's offshore oil and gas resources at about 50 billion barrels of oil equivalent, he said.Greenland's domestic energy goal is to be powered 100 percent by clean energy by 2030, Jerimiassen later told a press conference, up from the current 70 percent, which is mostly from hydropower.Greenland will set up a representative office in Beijing within a year, to boost trade ties with China, Nielsen said.Denmark and the United States have been concerned about China's interest in Greenland, notably over potential Chinese involvement in the financing and construction of airports.Greenland last month picked Denmark as a partner in the planned upgrade of two airports, having earlier shortlisted a Chinese firm for the job.

title: philip hammond theresea may budget
story: I know for many, the past few years haven’t been easy. But I’m happy to tell Sun on Sunday readers that their hard work is paying off.Our jobs market has defied many of the naysayers.Near record numbers of people have a job and unemployment has fallen in every region across the country.There are more than .million additional people in work since .While this is a huge achievement, sometimes it’s easy to forget that behind these numbers are thousands of people up and down our country who are now better able to provide for their families.They can get up every morning knowing they have the security that only a job can bring.And what’s more, they are being rewarded with a pay rise — this month’s figures show the strongest wage growth in almost a decade.Contrary to myths peddled by the opposition, it’s people at the bottom of the pay scale who have benefited most.The lowest earners working full-time have seen the fastest rise in pay thanks to our National Living Wage and the proportion of low-paid jobs is at a record low.Tomorrow I will deliver my Budget, where I will show how our careful focus on fixing the economy is bearing fruit.Thanks to the balanced approach we have taken — getting our debt falling, while keeping taxes low — and the hard work of the people of the UK, I will be able to set out how we will be investing in our future.Much of the talk surrounding Budgets is often technical. Many, many experts and commentators will have their own take on how the economy is doing.While this is, of course, important, what most ordinary people really care about is how the Budget will improve their day-to-day lives.And one of the issues which I know Sun on Sunday readers care a lot about is transport. With a thousand more people moving into work every day, it’s important that we help to get them there on time.Many of you preparing to start the working week tomorrow will know the frustration of having your journey to work ruined by delays caused by poorly maintained roads. Or of having your car or van damaged by potholes.This isn’t just a bad way to start the day, it’s bad for businesses large and small, and it can be really damaging to the wider economy as well.It’s estimated that congestion costs UK households more than £billion every year. That’s why tomorrow I will announce a bumper £billion investment in our country’s transport network — including a new £.billion fund ring-fencing vehicle excise duty raised in England for spending on our roads.As a former Transport Secretary, I know that these are the arteries that keep our country alive – and they need taking care of. Thirty-two years ago tomorrow, Margaret Thatcher officially opened the final stretch of the M.While few would claim to love this motorway, it’s easy to forget what a landmark moment this was for our country’s transport infrastructure. Three decades later, I am committed to honouring that legacy.And as important as our major roads are, smaller local roads are just as vital to our everyday lives.That’s why I will also announce tomorrow £million of immediate cash for councils to maintain and improve local roads — fixing potholes, repairing damaged roads and keeping bridges safe and open.A further £million on top of that will help improve local junctions, allowing better access to workplaces, high streets and other community facilities.This is also part of our commitment to bridging the gap between our regions. Those in rural parts of the country should have the same chances to get on in le and not have poor transport connections limiting their potential.The funding will help make journeys quicker and easier, while boosting productivity and improving access.And because I know that not everyone drives, I will also invest in local transport projects which could include new bus, tram and cycling routes.And I will also look to the future by investing in next-generation methods of transport, which could potentially include self-driving shuttle services.Not only could this revolutionise our transport network, it will also help us become a global leader developing future technologies.And finally, as I earlier announced with the Prime Minister, I am happy to confirm we will also be freezing fuel duty, for the ninth year in a row.This will keep the cost of fuel down for millions of drivers across the UK — saving people around £million this year alone.These measures are only possible due to our careful management of the economy over the past few years — and the hard work of the British people.This country has a bright future ahead, and — thanks to this vital investment package — the journey there just got a bit smoother.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chancellors 13bn budget priti patel
story: The Chancellor is set to announce an unexpected £ billion annual windfall in this week’s budget, which means he won’t have to take away more of what you earn and put up your taxes to fund the extra £ billion a year that has been promised for the NHS by .This is good news for taxpayers and also for our economy, as this is the largest annual change in borrowing forecasts since this data was first produced in  when Margaret Thatcher was Prime Minister.And there’s a reason for this windfall. It shows the strength and resilience of the UK economy alongside the efforts and hard work of families and households up and down the country.In conventional times voters might rightly expect the result of this to be lower taxes , more investment in our public services or to see progress in us paying off the ever ballooning national debt.Instead the Government is preparing to blow this cash - your money - by giving into even more of the EU’s demands.Until last week, Britain expected a  month “transition” or “implementation” period after we formally leave the EU next year on March , .Then, late last week the Government shocked everyone by proposing that we stay in the EU longer than we were originally told and that we extend the so called ‘negotiating period’ to leave the EU.Worse still, on Monday in the House of Commons, we were told that this transition period might last until June  – that’s six years after the referendum result. Whatever happened to Brexit means Brexit On top of our extended membership of the EU, we can expect a bill from the EU! That’s right more of your money with an extra price tag of approximately £ billion each year in contributions to the EU.The Treasury has budgeted for this until the end of  but for each year after , the cost will be as high as £ billion because we will have lost the £. billion a year rebate which was famously secured and successfully negotiated in  by Margaret Thatcher when she demanded our money back from the EU.The British people are once again being treated like fools. What we are now witnessing is a blatant attempt to keep Britain in the EU while Brussels continues to raid the pockets of British taxpayers.This must end and the Government should invoke the great Thatcherite spirit of Fontainebleau and say No, No, No to Brussels. Because pumping our money into an undemocratic and unaccountable system two years after Britain voted to leave the EU is simply not right or acceptable. It makes a mockery of our democracy and is an insult to the British public.It is our money and that money should be handed back to the people and communities across the UK to invest in our domestic priorities.It could help people across Britain– especially the least well off – by giving them back more of the money that they earn by cutting their taxes.For example,we cut the basic rate of income tax by a penny, that would cost us £ billion.By increasing the personal allowance by a £,, many more of the poorest paid households would be taken out of tax altogether, that’d cost us £. billion. Andwe cut beer and cider duty by  pence, that would cost us £. billion.So by easing the tax burden for the lowest paid and doing our bit to save British pubs from closing, we’d have invested £ billion into longer term economic growth in our economy.And with the other £ billion  How about supporting the millions of families who want to own their own home by cutting stamp duty for homeowners, we can again help the least well off and give them a hand up and support them in their aspirations to own their home.We could also take more first time buyers out of paying stamp duty altogether  If we raised the starting threshold of £, to £,, this would cost the Treasury £. billion.Then there’s the VAT we pay on domestic gas and electricity. The  per cent VAT charge on domestic fuel and power raised around £. billion in  . If we got rid of this we would make fuel cheaper and families would have a little extra left over in their monthly pay packets.What about the VAT charged on sanitary products for women  This should end now and not when we leave the EU s the Government previously promised, especially as leaving the EU will take longer than we were previously promised. VAT receipts from the sale of sanitary products costs approximately £. billion a year but importantly this one VAT cut that would unite women across the country.I could go on. There are so many important domestic key services and priorities to invest in.To govern is to choose and the choice being made our Government is to spend your money on an expensive and everlasting EU membership.And all this comes on top of the ridiculous capitulation where we have agreed to the EU’s demands to hand over a £ billion pay cheque for absolutely nothing in .Britain needs once again to have a long term economic plan that puts our national interest first.Let’s start standing up for Britain by investing in people, businesses and communities rather than the unelected and unaccountable bureaucrats of the European Union.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says budget just start
story: When we put them forward next March we will be an independent nation again.Even Philip Hammond will need to crack a smile.Because as we approach Brexit, the people of this country will want to hear details about the enormous benefits of our long, hard battle to finally wrest control from the EU.They will want to be told about lower taxes, cheaper goods and the biggest boost for business in our nation’s history.The Chancellor’s £billion spending proposals on social care and our roads in tomorrow’s budget are, of course, welcome.But they do not come near enough to the sort of good news we expect to hear on March .We would prefer Mr Hammond to tell us how he is going to put more money in people’s pockets.After all, what is the point of the Tories,they don’t stand for people keeping hold of more of their hard-earned cash We would also like the Chancellor to show his plans to kickstart Britain’s productivity, innovation and growth, across every corner of the country.Slashing business taxes will help private companies grow, whether big outfits or hard-working Sun on Sunday readers setting up small firms.We have the fourth-lowest home-ownership rate in the EU. If the Tories don’t address this, voters will punish them.Their long-term success depends on creating and sustaining a property-owning democracy.Once we are unshackled from Brussels, the whole world will open up for us.And we will have opportunity to properly prosper as an independent nation once again.Filling in our potholes is all well and good, but the Government must focus on laying the foundations to make sure Britain is on the road to a GREAT future.SOME good Brexit advice for the PM.Don’t be a pushover, walk in like you mean business and be prepared to wait for the best deal.But this guidance doesn’t come from the IMF, the BoE or even the IoD.It’s courtesy of a South London businessman: Mr Del Boy Trotter of Peckham.Theresa May could do worse than read his Sun column.Mais oui! title: new 50p coin brexit
story: The Chancellor will unveil advanced plans for the seven-sided p piece in his Budget.It will be available from March  next year, the day Britain exits the EU at pm.And in a bid to send out a positive signal to the world, it is expected to bear the phrase, ‘Friendship With All Nations’.The Sun has campaigned for the Government to create an enduring gesture to mark Brexit as a landmark national moment, such as a special stamp or coin.The commemorative coin has had to be personally signed off by the Queen, as it will bear her head.A source close to the Chancellor told The Sun: “It’s an historic moment which will rightly be commemorated”.Tory MPs will see the announcement as Mr Hammond’s bid to win round angry pro-Brexit Tory MPs after two years of battles with them.Senior Tory backbench Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg yesterday branded the Treasury a bastion of Remoanerism ahead of the annual national blueprint for taxes and spending.But Treasury sources say the department has been working on plans for the coin in secret for months, before Tory MPs began to lobby for one over the summer.Mr Hammond has now issued an order to the Royal Mint advisory committee to draw up a design for the coin, which will be signed off later this year.But The Sun has been told that the friendship with all nations phrase instead of any symbol is the firm preference of ministers for its reverse side.Mr Hammond wants to use the coin to ram home Brexit’s positive opportunities, as it is expected to be very popular with Leave voters.The coin will also have Brexit’s date on it, enshrined around the monarch’s image.It will have the Queen’s head on one side and the phrase “Friendship with all nations” on the other — exactly the type of positive, outward-looking message we want to send.Despite the Remain naysayers’ claims, Britain remains a top global financial, diplomatic and military power.Unshackled from the EU, we will boom as a global business hub by developing new relationships.Despite the Government’s commemorative move, the Royal Mail refuses to release a Brexit stamp, claiming our exit will not be “an important anniversary”. What a load of codswallop!They thought it was appropriate to issue stamps commemorating TV show Game Of Thrones and for when we joined the EEC in  and the Single Market in  . . .Royal Mail bosses clearly detest the democratic decision to leave the EU.But for them to pretend Brexit is not a genuinely signicant historical moment is first-class buffoonery.The Royal Mail – which is no longer under the Government’s control - has repeatedly refused to issue a commemorative Brexit stamp, insisting the event is still too politically controversial.A p coin was issued to mark Britain’s entry into the European Economic Community in , as well as our th anniversary of joining in .Commemorative coins were also made this year to mark Prince Harry and Meghan’s Royal Wedding and  years of the Royal Air Force.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: latest telethon shows us once and for all that c4s just a load of cake and balls
story: You watch BBC’s Children In Need, you’re getting Clare Balding, Doctor Who and dancers, whether you like it or not.ITV  It’d take sniper fire or a dinner setting next to Sir Phillip Green before Cowell was a no-show.Channel , though Apart from a bit of a secondhand cake-baking and Gogglebox, I was drawing a blank before Friday night.So it was with a mix of fascination and dread that I tuned into Stand Up To Cancer. A seven-hour slog live from Westminster City Hall, presented by Adam Hills, Maya Jama and the network’s spare part Alan Carr, who set the tone for most of what followed interviewing Foxy from SAS: Who Dares Wins.“It’s been announced you’ve got a new Stand Up To Cancer series starting next year. Tell us about it.”“I can’t.”“Give us some names.”“I can’t.”No sooner had we written that one off than it become apparent there was no Bake Off special either — just a promo for a show that will be screened months from now. No matter, though. With its lofty public-serving hat on, Adam Hills faithfully promised Channel  would “educate, entertain and inspire” us for the remainder of the evening, which must have looked quite good written down.In practice The first thing to say about Stand Up To Cancer is that it featured some of the most beautul and affecting films you’ll see on a telethon.They needed to be, as well, ’cos you don’t have to have watched the event to know it contained a lot of feeble stunts and sketches.I also could have lived without Adam Hills carrying out a threat to have his pubic hair waxed, live, once the total reached £million, and the educational segment, with Katherine Ryan and Chris O’Dowd, which was sunk the moment he announced: “We’re goingto put the humour in tumour.”Tellingly, there was also a fair bit of non-network talent involved, including James Corden.I’ll not dwell, though, on what Channel ’s Twitter feed did to the Carpool Karaoke segment, where Michael Buble talked about his son’s illness, except to say it was one of those productions where the left hand wasn’t talking to the right.So when Chris O’Dowd was moved to tears talking about the cancer films, the studio audience was guffawing loudly at Alan Carr manoeuvring himself into background position in a Prue Leith wig.By a process of elimination and production gaffs, though, it became apparent the centre of Channel ’s entire universe now is Gogglebox, which had created an all-star version with Louis Tomlinson, Danny Dyer and daughter Dani for the occasion.They missed a trick, frankly, by not capturing Louis falling asleep to The X Factor. But it was still riotously funny watching the regulars pick apart Naked Attraction, with the choicest comment being: “That one looks like Homer Simpson’s mouth.”This was not the sound of people laughing with the channel, though. They were laughing at it.A network that was once known for being brave and innovative is now far more readily associated with a genital parade, third-rate reality shows and cakes than anything in the way of ground-breaking drama or comedy.In fact, the only two genuinely funny people on its payroll are probably Jimmy Carr and Sean Lock, who had to make way, at Stand Up To Cancer, for box-ticking randoms like Mo Gilligan, who was served this testicular curve-ball by Maya Jama.“Do you have a special name for your balls, by any chance ”He does.The Big Narstie Show.So there I was, gently drting off as Darcey Bussell went through the technical motions on Strictly. “The control in the rise and fall. Strong in the two-three.”When, unless I’m imagining it, she told Sean Walsh: “You have to smooth it out and iron it out, so it isn’t jerking off or skippy.”Suddenly I was all ears for the show’s Halloween special – an event which, for three good reasons, is usually my least favourite of the run.Firstly, Tess always expects a laugh for referring to it as a “spook-tacular”. Secondly, someone does The ****ing Timewarp. And thirdly, the worst danceris forced to jig around to The Monster Mash.We got it all, on Saturday night, of course, yet somehow it didn’t feel quite such an endurance as normal.This may have been partly down to Ashley Roberts and Faye Tozer, who both danced like dreams, but it definitely owed something to the presence of Sean, who’s added real jeopardy to proceedings andactual comedy.His snog with Katya has made sense of a dreadful line-up and the BBC should be eternally grateful to The Sun and the photographer for capturing the moment.So although the handbag-clutchers will no doubt disagree, I was genuinely sad to see him voted off and probably back to the ex-girlfriend, where, in the words of Darcey Bussell, he’ll have to “smooth it out and iron it out” or he’ll end up, you know . . . “skippy”.Sandra Oh’s performance in Killing Eve. Aberdeen clinically dispatching some Glasgow-based team - in the Betfred Cup semi-final on Sunday.Nabhaan Rizwan heading towards the awards zone with BBC’s Informer, the best show currently on television.And the one positive to emerge from Luisa Omielan’s Politics For Bitches, which was the response from an estate agent when the “comedian” asked him what she’d have to do to afford a multi-million-pound mansion in London’s Little Venice.“Be funnier.”Since the last quarterly update, EastEnders has split into two distinct and very contrasting shows. There’s a brutal, gripping and addictive version set in Mick Carter’s prison wing, which seemed to have vanished into thin air a couple of weeks ago.And there’s the other, more familiar EastEnders we’re stuck with full-time now. A loud, grim and unforgiving place where Hayley Slater cannot decide between calling her unborn baby Stacey, in tribute to her cousin Jean, as a nod to the mad auntie, or Lee Marvin in honour of Big Mo.Worse still, though, is -year-old Keanu’s ongoing, very energetic affair with mighty Sharon Mitchell, , who’s attempted to cover the truth by claiming he’s her “personal trainer”. .“I gave him his job back,” she claimed, “He’s been getting me in shape.” The shape of what, though, is the question  An oval  A rhomboid Guy the Gorilla’s statue at London zoo An unflattering image, admittedly, but it’s nothing compared to the mental one Dot Cotton conjured up on Tuesday night, with readers of a fragile disposition advised to look away now: “Don’t play the innocent with me, Robbie Jackson. I know you’ve been fingering my Garibaldis.”See. I did warn you.This week’s winner is camp Frank, from The Apprentice, and US outlaw Jesse James.Sent in by Peter Budgen, via email. Picture research Alfie Snelling.This Morning, Rylan Clark-Neal: “Listen, you’re Martine McCutcheon, you’re a living legend.”Strictly, Tess Daly to Doctor Who’s Mandip Gill: “Congratulations on a brilliant series. It’s fantastic, isn’t it ” No.And X Factor, Ayda Field to Scarlett Lee: “You could sing the shopping list and I’d enjoy it.”Then you haven’t seen theof her shopping list.David Haye introducing himself to the winning Apprentice team as “the Hayemaker himself”.Channel  News managing to have a studio discussion about Press injunctions without anyone from the Press.The X Factor pretending Brendan Murray is “a plumber” rather than a professional musician managed by Louis Walsh.Dr Who’s latest right-on brain fart being Donald Trump and grime-loving spiders.And the BBC hiding The Mash Report behind a smokescreen of “satire” when everyone can see it’s simply spouting Auntie’s prejudices against the Tories, Brexit and working-class people.Just in case you weren’t already reminded of them on an almost hourly basis.Will there ever be a charity telethon without the deadening presence of John Bishop How come X Factor drag-act Thomas Pound’s alter-ego wasn’t Thomas Poundland Why did hardly anyone swear in Press  And where the hell did EastEnders’ prisoners all get their amazing suntans They look like they’ve just come off a fortnight’s golf in the Algarve, not a le stretch.Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which Elizabethan playwrite wrote A Midsummer Night’s Dream ”Stuart: “Pass.”The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “Kenneth Clark presented which landmark TV series on the history of art ”Andy: “The Antiques Roadshow.”Ben Shephard: “In which Latin American country is the ancient Mayan temple El Castillo ”Sue: “Egypt.”And Ben Shephard: “Northampton is the county town of which English county ”Kirsty: “Pass.”Jose Mourinho: “If Ronaldo has two touches, he can score a hat-trick.”Phil Thompson: “Elyounoussi is a flash in the pan all the time.”Steve McManaman: “United got a goal back with  minutes left and now it’s -, there’s even more time left.”Compiled by Graham WrayOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: glenn hoddle family overwhelmed by support
story: Hoddle had been appearing live on Robbie Savages show Saturday Morning Sav when he collapsed and cracked his head.His family said in a statement: Glenn and his family are overwhelmed by the best wishes sent from Tottenham Hotspur staff, players, ex-players and most importantly all our tremendous supporters since he was taken ill on Saturday.It has been a huge comfort to have your support and memories to lt us all at such a dficult time, so thank you. Lets hope for a win tonight to make Hod smile. COYS.Glenn Hoddle is showing signs he will make a full recovery after having major heart surgery.The former England manager,  is said to be up and speaking with friends and family just days after collapsing on set on BT Sport after suffering a massive heart attack.It’s thought the pundit is now out of intensive care and will suffer no long term health effects thanks to the quick efforts of BT sound engineer Simon Daniels.A pal of the former Spurs and Cha ace said: All the indications are that he is responding well to the treatment and could make a full recovery in the course of time.He had a good nights sleep and was talking on Sunday. Hes had major heart surgery.“Hes going to take some time to recover but there are no signs of brain damage and there are signs he is going to make a full recovery.Simon Daniels, a freelance sound engineer with BT, used a defibrillator to keep Hoddle alive after he suffered a heart attack at the studios on Saturday. Simon,  who is also a special constable, told The Sun yesterday: “It was nothing.”Glenn was taken ill shortly before he was due to appear as a pundit on the BT Sport Score show on Saturday.A statement on behalf of the family on Sunday said Hoddle remained in a serious condition but continues to respond well to treatment.The spokesman refused to comment that he was now out of intensive care.The football world has sent a flood of support to the former Spurs midfielder, who won  caps for England. England manager Gareth Southgate, who played under Hoddle for England, said: Everybody across the game is right behind one of English footballs greats and we are willing him to pull through.Greg Clarke, the FA chairman, added: All of us at Wembley and St Georges Park are thinking of Glenn and hoping for positive news. Our thoughts are also with his family and friends at what will be an extremely dficult time.Crystal Palace manager Roy Hodgson, a friend of Hoddle, said after his sides draw with Arsenal: I think its something which puts the game of football into perspective.

title: philip hammond budget cash public money
story: Philip Hammond spoke yesterday for more than an hour. There were announcements on schools funding, defence, moving “from disposable to reusable cups across all beverage types” — even a tax break for public loos. More money for social care and Universal Credit.Shopkeepers will breathe a sigh of relief at a hefty cut to business rates.There were hints of more money for the police. Sun readers will also welcome the tax freezes on beer, spirits, cider and short-haul flights.But the big bucks — some £.billion of the £.billion extra the Government expects to spend come - — went to the NHS, fulfilling the Prime Minister’s summer promise to increase spending as a th birthday present to a health service creaking under the strain of an ageing population.The question, of course, was how the Chancellor was going to pay for it.Before the Budget, all sorts of grim possibilities had been floated.Extra taxes on white-van men, lower- ing the VAT threshold and tightening the rules about National Insurance contributions. Taxes on plastic cups . Taxes on pretty much anything, really.Perhaps the best thing the Chancellor did in his Budget, then, was say “No”.To almost all of it. For an hour or more, I waited for the sting in the tail — the bit where Fiscal Phil turned Hatchet Hammond.But it never came. In paying for his promises — and above all, the NHS — the Chancellor was helped by better-than-expected borrowing forecasts, which showed our economy’s remarkable record of creating jobs is still going strong.But he has also made a calculation that it is better to live with a small and manageable deficit than try to drag the finances back into surplus at the cost of higher taxes. And that voters will see through Labour’s promises to hike borrowing back to stratospheric levels in the name of a socialist transformation of the economy.He decided, in other words, people pay enough tax already.And he’s right. All too often in recent years, it has felt like the answer to every problem — at least from Whitehall’s point of view — is higher taxes and more interference.Hammond was never going to copy his tax-slashing Tory predecessor Nigel Lawson, who made it a point of principle to abolish a dferent tax with every Budget.But at least he drew a line in the sand, deciding it is better when hardworking people get to keep more of their own money.That ending austerity should not, and must not, mean higher tax bills. That hard work should mean hard cash in your pocket.Yes, Hammond — like every Chancellor since Gordon Brown — made too many fiddly little announcements.But he avoided the kind of whacking- great raid on taxpayers’ pockets so many were urging him towards.This doesn’t mean we are out of the woods. Britain’s growth prospects over the next half-decade are still extraordinarily sluggish.The outcome of the Brexit deal will drastically change the fiscal picture.In many ways, Hammond’s speech yesterday was a holding action ahead of the much bigger decisions to come.We still need much more radical action to kickstart growth and productivity. Despite the scale of the housing crisis, for example, there was only tinkering around the edges.But a large part of delivering that growth must involve making the economy more dynamic, more competitive and letting people keep more of their own money as a reward for their efforts — moving the country in the direction outlined by Philip Hammond, rather than the one sketched out by Jeremy Corbyn .The overall verdict on the Budget  The jokes were worse than expected but the numbers were better.More spending on the NHS, tax cuts for millions of voters and the worst ideas kept out of it.Yes, borrowing will be higher — but low enough to keep us out of the danger zone and far, far lower than under a Corbyn government.That is a menu Philip Hammond will be pretty happy with.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: fascists rally mussolini hometown predappio
story: Far-right militants have gathered in Predappio to mark Il Duce’s rise to power with the March on Rome.Around , blackshirts gathered in the Italian capital to demand the resignation of the then Prime Minister Luigi Facta on the night of October  to , .In the rally to mark this march, many can be seen giving the fascist salute, which is not outlawed in the country despite its past.In one image a group of men give a right-arm salute while holding a banner of Mussolini.Another picture shows a woman dressed in a baseball cap and t-shirt with the word “Auschwitzland” and an outline of the death camp on it.In a third a man appears to be dressed in a black World War II-era military unorm.The far right militants in Italy have been encouraged due to the country’s sht to the right with the rise of the populist, Eurosceptic and anti-immigration Five Star Movement and its blocking of a parliamentary bill which was aimed at banning fascist salutes and the sale of Mussolini memorabilia.Earlier this year the party, lead by Luigi Di Maio, became the largest single party in the countrys parliament.It secured . percent of the vote and  seats, not enough to secure an overall majority though and the party is largely dependent on the Lega Nord for support.Thousands travel to Mussolini’s birthplace every year and souvenir shops sell fascist-themed souvenirs like coffee mugs that have the slogans: Believe, Obey and Fight.Born on July , , Mussolini was the leader of the country’s Partito Nazionale Fascista– PNF.He became Prime Minister in  after the March on Rome and effectively became a dictator in  and ruled until .Mussolini became known as Il Duce .Initially Mussolini had joined the Socialist Partybut was expelled for supporting military intervention in the First World War.After the war his views focused on “revolutionary nationalism”.Following the Abyssinia Crisis in - he invaded Ethiopia which was widely condemned by the Western Powers but he got the backing of Germany’s leader Adolf Hitler.Hitler and Mussolini formed what was called the Rome-Berlin Axis and signed a treaty of co-operation.On June ,  Italy joined the Second World War, on the side of Germany.In October that year Mussolini sent Italian forces into Greece although it was unsuccessful and the counter-offensive pushed the forces back to Albania.Italy also suffered a humiliating defeat when it joined with Germany in launching an attack on the Soviet Union.Mussolini also suffered a defeat when the Axis Powers were crushed in North Africa..In July  the Grand Council of Fascism passed a motion of no confidence in Mussolini and on July  the king dismissed him as head of the government.He was held in custody until he was rescued by German troops.Mussolini then tried to flee the country with his mistress Clara Petacci to Switzerland but both were captured by communist partisans and executed by firing squad.His body was then taken to Milan was it was hung upside down at a petrol station to publicly confirm his death.The far-right Forza Nuova party had announced a march called the “March of Patriots” in Rome for October  but the Interior Minister Marco Minniti said any march would be illegal.Speaking in parliament in September he said that any event like that “clearly recall[ed] the birth of the fascist regime and would clearly contrast with the legal order.In response to the initial criticism, Forza Nuovas leader Roberto Fiore denied any fascist or nostalgic element to the march, and called it a walk for security.

title: after years of grim penny pinching budgets we must say nice one chancellor
story: Like the bumper tax cut for million workers, a year earlier than promised.The £billion NHS injection, the £billion bailout for defence, hundreds of millions for our pock-marked roads and hard-up schools. Another £.billion to iron out Universal Credit problems. A near five per cent hike in the minimum wage. A big, welcome cut in business rates for struggling firms.New ideas flowed: a levy on web giants’ UK revenues, potentially raising £million, is long overdue — though Philip Hammond must ensure the ­burden does not fall on online shoppers.There was major funding to help councils transform our hollowed-out High Streets, including turning vacant shops into homes. A huge increase in firms’ annual investment allowance will let them deduct from taxable profits up to £million spent on tools and machinery.Heathrow’s e-gates will now speed up entry for visitors from the US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Japan as well as Europe — a symbol of a global Britain open for business.Some bad ideas The Sun has criticised, including the proposed “latte levy” on plastic cups, were binned. Duty was frozen again on fuel, as well as beer.Even the OBR’s normally pessimistic forecasts were on Mr Hammond’s side. Growth is predicted to rise steadily, albeit too slowly. Unemployment is set to fall to its lowest in  years.We wish the Chancellor had outlined more radical, visionary low-tax measures. He will need them should Brussels shove us into a no-deal Brexit. But that gripe aside, what was not to like The Tories must not try to ape Corbyn’s £trillion spending fantasy. But it is not “Corbyn-lite” to spend billions fixing Britain’s most pressing problems, evenwe are still running a deficit.As for Corbyn himself, it was obvious he took in barely a word of the Budget.In his “response” he merely recited his normal scripted complaints, flubbing his words and shouting randomly, as is now traditional. He somehow contrives to make even this chaotic Government look like a model of competence.Budgets often unravel when acres of small print are finally scrutinised.But for now... nice one, Chancellor.ANGELA Merkel is a once-brilliant politician scuppered by an arrogant disregard for voters.For years she was admired worldwide. Then she flooded Germany with a million migrants, enraging the public, fuelling extremism and sealing her own downfall.Don’t expect Brussels to learn from it.Their contempt for citizens is even worse. And it will do for them too.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: businesswoman caught swerving all over the road when double the alcohol limit told cops she didnt know her colleagues had been topping up her drink on works night out
story: Rachel Hind, , was stopped by cops when they saw her Audi A swerving onto the wrong side of the road after she left an Italian restaurant.Hind had just treated  colleagues to dinner, but on her way home at am police officers had to take evasive action in their patrol van to avoid hitting Hinds car.When whey asked her to get out of her car, the registered nurse struggled to get her keys out of the ignition.She was also staggering in her high heels with slurred speech, glazed eyes and her breath smelling heavily of alcohol, the court heard.It emerged the mum-of-two had been drinking Prosecco, gin and tonic and double vodkas with cola during one of her regular evenings out to thank their employees before heading to her £.million home in High Legh, near Knutsford, Cheshire.At Manchester Magistrates Court Hind admitted drink driving but tried to argue against disqualication claiming she thought she was sober at the time.She added that she did not realise a colleague had unwittingly topped up her drinks throughout the evening in the belief she was getting a taxi home.She claimed she was only swerving around in the road as she was attempting to avoid potholes. JPs banned her for  months and fined her £, with costs of £.The incident occurred at .am on June  this year after Hind had left the Italian Job restaurant in Urmston after the party had spent up to six hours eating and drinking.John Richards prosecuting said: The police evidence says she was swerving around.She was unsteady on her feet, her eyes were glazed and her speech was slurred. She was staggering and her breath stank of alcohol and she needed help into the police van.The crown say it would have been patently obvious to her that she was over the limit. You might think it’s strange that she didn’t realise her Prosecco had been topped up. In a short period of time, the glass goes from half full to full - how did she not realise that In terms of the vodka and cola, evenit was the case that you’re dealing with single shots, you’re going to knowit’s got alcohol in it. But we are talking about doubles here. The crown says that it doesn’t stack up that she didn’t realise.Tests showed Hind, who specialises in end-of-le care at her two care homes, blew a reading of  microgrammes of alcohol in  millilitres of breath. The legal limit is mg.She told the hearing: Every quarter of the year I take the staff out for a meal and drinks and to say thank you. I take them to an Italian restaurant and they have an open bar. I just pay the bill and let them have what they want.I would always drive there and drive home. Very occasionally, I would get a taxi but on that day I drove. I was on call that night which means I am in charge of running the night sht. I ordered a single gin and tonic.I always would have a gin and tonic and maybe a glass of ProseccoI was having a three-course meal.She added: There were jugs of water all along the table which I had some of. I also had about four to five glasses of coke and I also had a glass of Prosecco with my main meal which was at about ish. I felt fine. I didn’t feel drunk, I felt fine to drive - I didn’t think I was taking a risk. I gave my colleague a lt home, which I wouldn’t have doneI felt drunk.But the road was full of potholes. It did occur to me that I hope the police don’t think I am a drunk driver because I am swerving to avoid the potholes. I have had four punctures in two years on that car from potholes.But I didn’t think I caused the police van to swerve. The police woman told me to open my car and I told her that I needed to shut the car door to turn off the engine - I did struggle to get the car keys out when I did this.I told the officer from the very beginning that I had been drinking, but it was only one gin and tonic and a glass of Prosecco over the course of a three course meal. I struggled out of the police van, but I was wearing high heels and I don’t normally wear them.I had a terrible row with my husband about it afterwards. I was disappointed in myself and I went into a spell of depression. I couldn’t tell anybody at work about it because I am their employer and I am supposed to be an example to them.She claimed a colleague Amanda Jackson later confessed to topping up her drinks during the evening during a heart-to-heart meeting and added: She went white in the face and said ‘I’m sorry, but I topped your drinks up that night.’She didn’t know I was driving home and she told me that she had been giving me drinks. She said she topped up my Prosecco once and that she had put Vodka and Cokes on the table.If I am drinking alcohol, it’s only gin and tonic that I am drinking which I know the smell and taste of. I don’t drink vodka. I have never been a vodka and cola - it just tasted of cola.Retrospectively, I can see now that I was drunk but at no point did I feel over the limit at the time, I was talking to my colleague all the way home in the car.My cousin died after being hit by an articulated lorry and my best friends nephew was also hit by a drunk driver. I haven’t drink driven until this incident where I unknowingly got into my car while over the limit and drove.Work colleague Miss Jackson admitted unwittingly getting doubles for her boss.She said: I made sure that the drinks and food were going to the right people. I went to the bar a couple of times and ordered about four vodka and cokes each time and I just brought them to the table and put them down there.I saw she was drinking coke but I didn’t realise she was supposed to be drinking normal coke.I was just going around the table filling the glasses up. I filled them all up.When she told me what happened I said ‘Oh my god, I am so sorry I bought you some drinks and I didn’t know you weren’t drinking.’It’s all my fault and she’s in all this trouble and I didn’t know she wasn’t drinking. She is my boss and she is amazing at what she does, and I feel terrible and will take the consequences.I am not going to lie, I was quite drunk that night - about a  .”Hinds lawyer Miss Stephanie Varle said: “In the UK, a lot of people drink a small amount of alcohol and drive.You have heard that she reasonably believed that she drank a gin and tonic and a glass of Prosecco and was safe to drive home. She did go out and consume some alcohol, which the law permits her to do - but she didn’t notice her drink had been topped up.This is a woman who works  hours and was on call on that evening. I submit that when she was moving around, she would not notice an odourless drink. She was driving at a normal speed and was simply trying to circumnavigate the potholes in the road.The alcohol limit does unfortunately permit people to lawfully get behind the wheel of a car after some drink.But JP Edward Tasker, said: Having heard all the evidence, we don’t accept that the defendant didn’t know that the drinks didn’t have alcohol in them.

title: giant rat invasion foot long bristol
story: The woman, who asked not to be named, spotted the giant rodents scurrying along her turfed balcony in the Lockleaze area of Bristol.The mum said the first-floor balcony of her housing association home had become infested along with neighbours properties.She told the Bristol Post: Something needs to be done to cure this problem for good. They have chewed through the walls of the building to get across to each property.My children have noticed them but theyre a bit young to understand.She said she now wont let her children - aged one, four and five - play outside.Bristol-based United Communities housing association said the entire city has been suffering from rat infestations.Jayme Whittleson, control manager at the housing association, said: This was first reported to us on Facebook and straight away we attended.The bins were in a very reasonable order, they werent overflowing.Rats are an issue all over the city.This summers heatwave brought a plague of giant rats across the UK.Experts say there could now be as many as  million rats across Britain.We pay for your stories!
