title: budget 2018 public spending rise no deal brexit philip hammond
story: Britains leading economics wonks predicted that the squeeze on spending is set to continue.The Institute for Fiscal Studies added that the Chancellor could end up borrowing billions more after committing extra cash to services and tax cuts.Mr Hammond yesterday cut taxes for million Brits as he announced he was boosting spending by £billion over the coming years.But IFS director Paul Johnson said today: This is no bonanza. Many public services are going to feel squeezed for some time to come.Cuts are not about to be reversed. If I were a prison governor, a local authority chief executive or a headteacher I would struggle to find much to celebrate. I would be preparing for more dficult years ahead.He said the Budget was a bit of a gamble as Mr Hammond took advantage of unexpected improvements in the public finances - and warned the gamble could backfire.Mr Johnson said there was a one in three chance that the public finances could get worse next year, and predicted the Chancellor would have to ramp up borrowing even though Britains debt already stands at an eye-watering £.trillion.He said: Any idea that there is a serious desire to eliminate the deficit by the mid-s is surely for the birds.The economist described how Mr Hammond had increased funds for the NHS and Universal Credit, while keeping most other spending flat.He concluded: Does that add up to the end of austerity  On a narrow definition perhaps it does, on wider definitions it doesn’t - at least not yet.Assessing the impact of Mr Hammonds tax cuts, Mr Johnson revealed that million Brits have been taken out of income tax altogether thanks to Tory policies over the past eight years.The Chancellor today claimed he would pump even more cash into the economywe end up quitting the EU without a Brexit deal.Speaking this morning, he admitted his plans would involve higher public spending to help the economy remain stable.Mr Hammond told the BBC: If the economy suffers a shock - and a No Deal Brexit is an example of a shock... we will deal with it in the usual way.Very often a shock to the economy actually requires a boost to spending in the short term to support demand and to keep the economy going.He added thatBritain and the EU do strike a good deal, spending could rise anyway as the economy grows.Speaking in Norway, Theresa May backed Mr Hammonds approach of mixing more spending with cuts to taxes - saying: Austerity coming to an end isnt just about more money into our public services, its about more money in peoples pockets as well.Yesterday, we confirmed that announcement that we had made in the summer of giving the biggest single injection of extra money into our National Health Service in its history.When we first said it in the summer we suggested we might have to raise taxes, we would have to raise taxes, to fund part of that.What was clear in the Budget yesterday is we have fully funded that - extra money into our NHS and not raising taxes.Indeed, we have cut taxes for million people.Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell accused Mr Hammond of handing out tax cuts in order to buy off voters ahead of a possible snap election.He said: The Tories usually do this. If a General Election is coming, what theyll do is theyll splash out some money and thenthey win the election they then start cutting it back again.Mr Hammond denied trying to bribe the electorate, saying: What we are preparing for is Britains future.Weve now turned a corner and we are able to give Britain a bit of good news.He also insisted he is still hoping to balance the Budget despite cutting taxes and increasing spending.A snap opinion poll shows that most Brits back the Chancellors decision to turn on the spending taps after eight years of austerity.Some  per cent said boosting public services should be Mr Hammonds priority, with only  per cent calling for more deficit reduction.But critics today accused the Budget of squeezing poorer workers and forcing the burden of austerity on to women.The left-wing Resolution Foundation thinktank said  per cent of the tax cuts will go to wealthier families.Director Torsten Bell said: Income tax cuts announced yesterday will overwhelmingly benefit richer households, with almost half of the long-term gains going to the top ten per cent of households.On public services, the NHS saw a big-spending boost - but unprotected departments still have further cuts pencilled in.And senior Labour MP Yvette Cooper claimed  per cent of the impact of austerity had fallen on women - adding: The gender gap in the Tories tax and benefit policies is getting worse.

title: boy crystal meth seizure halloween galion ohio
story: Braylen Carwell, from Galion, Ohio, began shaking when he ed from collecting candy on Sunday and was rushed to hospital.While it was initially thought his sweets has been tainted with meth, the boy insists the only thing he put in his mouth before the seizure was a pair of plastic vampire teeth.Police have sent the novelty dentures, which he was given while out trick-or-treating, away to be tested.Investigators also retrieved the sweets which Braylen had been given and collected them as evidence after his parents had thrown them out.His mother Julia Pence described the moment her son began having a seizure.She told Fox : “The left side of his face was just droopy and then he fell and then he couldn’t move his left arm.“And he didn’t know where he was, he didn’t know what he was doing.”Julia says the little boy is still feeling the effects from the powerful drug.She said: “You can tell he is still coming down from it because one minute he is all hyper and the next minute he is tired.The distraught mother admitted to cops that she and the boy’s father are recovering drug addicts, reports TV.But she insists they have both been sober for sometime and strongly denied having anything to do with Braylen’s positive drugs test.She said: “Im not covering up the truth. Im just speaking the truth of what happened to my son, yesterday.“Nobody in my family ordads family would drug my children.The five-year-old’s dad said hed taken his kids trick-or-treating for about two hours on Sunday afternoon.He said his son had only had a couple of pieces of candy and was playing with some sort of fake teeth, according to police.Police Chief Brian Saterfield said: “Right now, there’s nothing specic. We need to narrow it down to seethere was in fact something that was tainted.”Cops are urging parents to check their children’s sweet and any other items they are given during Halloween trick-or-treating.

title: photos streets britain colourful crazy side life blighty
story: Paramedic Chris Porsz walked hundreds of miles around  cities since  taking quirky pictures of everyday le, from pensioners and party-goers to buskers to bikers.The -year-old from Peterborough has now published a book, Streets Of Britain, featuring more than  pictures from UK cities.The photos offer a unique snapshot of le in Britain today, with pictures of people singing, screaming and scooting.Chris said: I have walked many miles over the years, unsure exactly what I am looking for but I just know when I see it and then snap!.Its usually something surreal, bizarre, someone a bit eccentric who stands out from the madding crowd or everyday people caught up in some humorous interaction.Chris caught the photography bug after buying a camera when his first child Simon was born in .He began walking the streets of his home town of Peterborough for inspiration and quickly developed a passion for street photography. He later decided to hone his craft by visiting other cities.Chris said: Some cities were full of characters, such as Brighton, and it was easy to get lots of good pictures, but others I had to keep ing to until I got what I needed. Ive tried to capture a snapshot of a day in each of the cities.He added that sometimes it would be frustratingsomeone walked in front of the camera at the wrong time or he missed the moment, but other pictures would then make up for it.He added: My near misses would fill another book, but any moments of dejection and self-doubt are soon forgotten when I see a man in Newcastle wearing a pink suit and a horses head, or a pensioner walking around Nottingham with an owl on his arm, as you do.I cannot resist snapping the drunken hens and their inevitable here I am, tadar! pose. Every town too has its fire and brimstone brigade so I just wait patiently for a sinner to come along to make a lucky juxtaposition.Chris said his work as a paramedic at Peterborough City Hospital helped with his street photography as he was able to reassure complete strangers and react instinctively to the unexpected.Sometimes Chris would talk to the subjects of his photos and discover an even more exciting story - the front cover of his book is one of his favourites.He explained: The lady was about  and lived in Peterborough and was describing how as a young girl on Bonfire Night she set off a rocket and it went through the window of a policemans house and burnt it down.Although it looks like she is giving the finger, she is actually putting her finger up to demonstrate the rocket going in the air.

title: mum in tears after universal credit blunder leaves her with 74p to live on for a week
story: Melissa Whitchurch, , and her partner Chris Steer,  desperately rummaged around their home looking for things to sell so that they could buy food for their five-year-old daughter Cheyenne - because of a late payment of their benefits.The couple, from Brighton, were expecting a Universal Credit payment of £ to be paid into their bank account last week and planned their finances around it.But when Melissa went to take out the money, she was horried to see her balance was just  pence and called the Department for Work and Pensionshotline for help.Melissa claimed the officer said the payment was not due for another six days and, when she tried to explain the mistake, told her it was her problem and hung up.Melissa said: All that was going through my mind was how am I going to feed my daughter and send her to school without her snacks She went on: It breaks my heart to think of her feeling like the odd one out, sat there watching everybody  eat their fruit when she doesnt have any.Melissa, who is signed off work due to mobility problems, had originally asked the DWP to change her payment schedule from a monthly arrangement to a fortnightly one.The family received a payment of £ and were told the other half of that would appear two weeks later.They used the cash to pay off bills and get them food to last the next few weeks, but the other half didnt arrive.Shes just one of many Brits who have had problems with the new benefits system, Universal Credit, which rolls six payments into one.Yesterday the Chancellor revealed that Brits will be able to get more help moving onto Universal Credit - but those changes won’t come in until .Former shop assistant Melissa, who has to take  tablets a day for her health, said: Me and my partner can go without, but not our little girl.If we were told this in the first place, we would have budgeted for it.Its horrible. Cheyenne is really sweet about it and she doesnt really understand, thank goodness.We try to keep her away from it.But when she sees Im upset, she will come over and cuddle me and say its okay mummy. Its horrible and the people that are supposed to help just dont care.They are heartless.And she avoided going to the food bank for help because she was expecting to be paid on time.Kind strangers and neighbours have been helping her out with food in the meantime.Partner Chris was also signed off work as a chef for mental health reasons.A DWP spokesperson said: The vast majority of claimants are paid in full and on time, and are comfortable managing their money. Advance payments and budgeting support is available for anyone who needs extra help.Universal Creditreplaces an out-of-date, complex benefits system with clf edges that disincentivised work and often trapped people in unemployment. Under UC, evidence shows people are moving into work faster and staying in work longer.

title: worlds most extreme haunted house where guests are waterboarded has up to 500 people a day apply to take part over halloween
story: McKamey Manor is run by Russ McKamey in San Diego, Calornia, where a few participants every day are bound, slapped and even compelled to eat their own vomit.Guests are put through a psychological nightmare – having their heads shaven and on even claiming to have been waterboarded.Owner, Russ, receives anywhere between  and  request a day to attempt his extreme haunt venue, which is currently fully booked through December  and has never been completed.Guests are made to sign a waiver before they take part and McKamey insists on doing a background check to ensure those taking part do not have any serious medical conditions.The list of ,-plus people is simply the shortlist in case others drop out at the last minute, Russ, , said, and he currently runs the show with the help of only one other person.A tarantula crawls over a womans face as she is held down in the the hell houseAnother appears to be covered in blood in a chest freezer during the ordealDespite this a guest suffered a heart attack during the experience in , McKamey told .Special effects, animatronics, actors and live animals such as tarantulas, spiders and rats are used to send guests away shivering and crying.McKamey films each volunteer to make a mini movie of each ordeal which are then posted on his YouTube channel which has nearly  million views.The haunted house experience has been called the worlds scariestThough he says he’s invested more than half a million dollars into the event, animal lover McKamey doesnt ask his guests for any money – just a dog food donation for Operation Greyhound.He told Fox News: It really is like watching somebody live their own horror movie right there, six inches in front of their face.”While no one was ever lasted the full eight hours, McKamey says that in  the record holder, known as Sarah P, lasted six hours inside the house before giving up.Some of its most extreme moments occur on a morgue table, including the use of a live tarantula.McKamey said: You want to see true fear  You put live spiders crawling on somebodys face, and the tears are just flowing down their eyes in silence.“Its like youre watching a silent movie.”The fright fan says he does it for the love of the haunt, simply wanting to put on the biggest, craziest show anyones ever seen.In , Amy Milligan, of East County, San Diego, claimed she had been waterboarded at the haunted house – an allegation McKamey strongly denied.She told the San Diego Union-Tribune that her head was repeatedly pushed under water while her hands were tied.Milligan claimed that actors pushed her under the water again and again despite her begging for the experience to stop.She said: “You give them so much trust and they just break it by waterboarding you and slapping you.But McKamey denied those claims, telling the Union Tribune: “We do not waterboard, we do not even kind of waterboard.“It’s psychological what we’re doing. They’re safe all the time.”McKamey Manor was recently featured on an episode of Netflix series Dark Tourist.

title: zante earthquake magnitude tremors latest updates
story: The quake struck today in the same location as the mega tremors hit last week.Todays tremor hit at about .pm local time and there were reports it could be felt in Athens and Piraeus in Greece.It was also reported the earthquake was felt in Pyrgos and Kefalonia.There are no reports of damage to buildings, injuries and Zante is at no risk of tsunami, officials say.Zakynthos Mayor Pavlos Kolokotsas told Greek state broadcaster ERT: “We are not facing any particular problems. Calm is being restored.”As previously reported, Brit tourists were among those caught up in the tremor last week, which was also felt in Greeces capital, Athens, and as far away as Italy and even Africa.The massive tremor struck in the dead of night on the country’s west coast.Laura Sallabanks, , from Coningsby, Lincs, said her nine-year-old daughter was left “shaken” after rushing out of their accommodation in the Alykes area.She told Sun Online: “We woke up to a smaller quake, half hour before the big one which set things rattling in our rooms.“The big quake lasted a couple of minutes and felt like the whole building was swaying around us.Power was lost in the capital and main town, also called Zakynthos.The fire service said rockfalls were reported in another part of the island, where boulders crashed onto a packed beach sending tourists fleeing just last month.And part of a church wall collapsed on the mainland town of Pyrgos, in the southern Peloponnese area.Several of people were treated for minor injuries.Civil protection agency press spokesman Spyros Georgiou said a precautionary tsunami warning was issued.British Geological Survey seismologist Margarita Segou told The Sun Online: Greece and Italy have the largest seismic hazard, as we say, which means that earthquakes are more frequent there.

title: woman shares weird food habit and people reply with their own and one really topped them all
story: But when Aussie comedian Felicity Ward shared her own particularly weird eating habit online, the ensuing response of distasteful food confessions was enough to make most sick to their stomachs.Felicity wrote: I eat kiwi fruit skin-on, like an apple, and I sometimes enjoy orange juice, instead of milk, on my Weetbix.What is your food habit that other people shame you for Followers were then quick to pile in with their horrid gustatory habits.Jo Horsman said: Ive always liked salt and vinegar crisps dipped in melted chocolate.When the trend for salted caramels came in I realised I was ahead of my time.Jan Schmidt made the chilling admission: I like pouring cream on my ice cream.And Amy Elizabeth Wood wrote: Weetabix with cheese and butter. [Or] cream cheese and salami. Its like a really big cracker.My family call it Weetabix toast.And it also turns out that Felicity wasnt alone in her hairy-kiwi-eating confession.Hann Kopp Young exclaimed: I THOUGHT I WAS THE ONLY ONE THAT ATE KIWI SKINWhile another user said: Im another kiwi like an apple person.I thought negative reactions might have calmed down over the years but, nope, eyebrows raised still.But of all the appalling eating revelations, Jolene Dovers proposal surely takes the biscuit.She confessed to: Eating starburst with the wrapper on.Unbelievably, Rosie Wyatt replied: I do this tooooo. Its not proper paper and who has the time to unwrap that s**t !When askedthe sweets are wrapped in plastic, Jolene doubled-down on environmentalist grounds, saying: Probably. Save the turtles.

title: deaf boy 6 farted in a classroom and his reaction made everyones day
story: The youngster “farted loudly” but had no idea “hearing people” would know when he had let one rip.First-grade teacher Anna Trupiano, who works at Kendall Deomnstration Elementary School in Washington DC, documented what happened in a social media post.Her message has since gone viral after actress Minnie Driver shared her post and it has now been liked thousands of times.Anna wrote: “Today in first grade one of my deaf students farted loudly in class and other students turned to look at them.“The following is a snippet of a -minute conversation that happened entirely in American Sign Language among the group of deaf students and I.”The boy asked her why fellow students were looking at him and she said “because they heard you fart”.He was horried to learn that hearing people can hear farts and another child asked: “How do you know which farts they can hear and which farts they can’t ”Anna replied: “You know how sometimes you can feel your butt move when you fart  A lot of those they can hear.“Butyour butt doesn’t move it’s more likely they didn’t hear it.”The boy who farted then used sign language to shout: “TELL THEM TO STOP LISTENING TO MY FARTS! THAT IS NOT NICE!”Anna explained to the class that farting is “healthy” and “everyone does it” including the pupils’ parents.She ended the hilarious thread by writing: “I went to college for eight years to have these conversations”.Her post has been met with hundreds of comments from people who enjoyed her transcript of what was said.Minnie Driver said: “In all the sadness of this weekend, I wanted to share a thread that I know will remind you there is good and laughter and revelation in the world still.”A social media user wrote “There’s so much awesome in this little thread” whole another added “I laughed SO HARD at this thread. THANK YOU!”

title: the last budget before brexit but a deal hasnt happened yet
story: The deficit should have been closing in on zero. Instead, it is left at a persistent #bn or so.So the government retrospectively funded the promise made by the PM for the biggest ever cash increase in NHS funding, but did so without raising taxes.In fact it cut them a bit by accelerating to this coming April, the rise in basic rate and higher rate income tax thresholds to #, and #, respectively.At the time of that announcement in summer, even at the Conservative Party conference, the Chancellor had suggested that these spending rises would be at least partly funded by tax rises.Not so, according to these numbers. But they may yet materialise on the other side of the Brexit fog.In that respect - the extra spending on the NHS, not funded by a tax rise - there was an end to austerity politics. But Mr Hammond was pointed in claiming austerity was coming to an end, rather than actually over. The government has calculated that there is no prize for a cash surplus.The claim about austerity itself was more debatable.The expected "fiscal envelope" for the spending review was conspicuous by its absence. It will be decided next year, though indicative figures were given. That is code for "after Brexit".,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey"" data-targeting-"" data-tag"" data-component-name"sdc-site-mpu" aria-label"Advertisement" id"mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance""

title: wh smiths 155m us deal sees further shift from uk high street
story: The only purchases made by WH Smith in the s were small in-fill acquisitions such as UNS, an operator of retail outlets and coffee shops in hospitals, for just #m in  and  stores from the failed British Bookshops and Stationers chain in  for a mere #m.So Tuesdays acquisition of InMotion, the US digital accessories retailer, is quite a dramatic step by the standards of this venerable old company.The mdeal represents WH Smiths biggest acquisition for nearly two decades.It is also very much in keeping with WH Smiths strategy.InMotion, based in Jacksonville, Florida, operates  stores across  airports in the US and buying it will double the size of WH Smiths international travel business.While many people assume that WH Smith, founded in , makes most of its money from its traditional high street stores, it is actually its travel business - taking in outlets at airports, railway stations, hospitals and workplaces - that has been the main growth generator in recent years on the back of the boom in air travel.The travel business has grown profits in each of the last  years and now accounts for two-thirds of group operating profit.The importance of the travel arm was shown by the trading update accompanying the deal announcement.During the first eight weeks of WH Smiths financial year, which began on  September, total sales in the travel business were up % on the same period last year and up % on a like-for-like basis .

title: philip hammonds brexit blindness mirror
story: NewsopinionPhilip Hammonds Brexit blindness: Mirror Politics morning briefingThe Budget failed on two counts: it increased inequality and it failed to offer a bold agenda for post-Brexit BritainShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  OCT NewsopinionThe congratulations could be short lived "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email If there was a phrase which will come to define yesterday’s Budget it was Philip Hammond’s handing poundmillion for schools to buy “the little extras they need.” The Chancellor has a reputation for political deafness but this was especially insensitive. The little extras headteachers need include not having to close their schools early, not having to cancel music and swimming lessons, not having to lay off teaching assistants and not having to beg parents for items such as toilet paper and stationery. Hammond’s choice of words pointed to a deeper problem. It implied that teachers and parents should be grateful for his largesse. But when you have put someone in hospital, you should not be surprisedthe patient then takes umbrageyou come round with a bunch of grapes and words of comfort. The Resolution Foundation think tank delivered its verdict on the Budget this morning and found it was deeply regressive. The Tories like to spin the raising of the income tax threshold as evidence of how they are helping the just about managing but it is a tax cut which is skewed towards the better off and does nothing for the five million people who earn too little to pay the tax.According to the Resolution Foundation, % of the income tax cuts announced yesterday will go to the top half of earners. The richest tenth of households are set to gain  times as much in cash terms next year from the income tax and benefits giveaways in the Budget as the poorest tenth of households . The small print tells a dferent narrative to that presented by the Chancellor. Once you strip away the increase in NHS spending then there is almost nothing for other departments. Even the extra pound.billion for the universal credit is offset by the poundbillion of welfare cuts being imposed by the Tories. Hammond framed his Budget as an example of how the Conservatives were balancing the ending of austerity with continued fiscal discipline. This was a sleight of hand when the figures show the strictures will remain in place for several years to come. The giveaways masked a bigger issue: the Chancellor has limited room to manoeuvre until Brexit is resolved. Everything is predicated upon Theresa May securing a deal.

title: philip hammond snaps tv clash
story: NewsPhilip Hammond SNAPS in TV clash with Susanna Reid over utterly insulting schools cash in the BudgetThe Tory claimed his fund - worth just £k per primary or £k per secondary - was supposed to be a "nice gesture" as he faced furyShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video philip-hammond-angry-budget-clash-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChancellor Philip Hammond squirmed on live TV today as he was blasted over his utterly insulting promise of poundm for schools. The Tory claimed his fund - worth poundk per primary or poundk per secondary this year - would help buy the little extras teachers need. But it comes after years of cuts and pleas by head teachers for supplies as basic as pens and paper. Today the Chancellor told ITVs Good Morning Britain “I just thought that would be a nice gesture” so schools could buy a whiteboard, buy a couple of computers. He insisted schools could get more funds in next years spending review and it’s nothing to do with mainstream schools funding - it was simply a little extra.  But Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell said people were really angered by the remark. And GMB host Susanna Reid told him: What is happening in schools where theyre considering shorter weeks. They cant buy essentials! The Chancellor snapped: Frankly I reject that. Frankly I reject that. Schools funding will be dealt with in the spending review.  We put pound.bn additional money into schools funding last year to protect per pupil spending. What I did yesterday was nothing to do with that process - i was simply giving back a little bit of the money weve saved this year so schools can buy the odd little piece of kit that they need. I think thats a nice gesture. Many of the schools I know would be very happy to have pound, or even pound, to buy a whiteboard, buy a couple of computers, whatever it is. The money, announced in yesterdays Budget speech, has been allocated as capital spending. Capital funds are ringfenced for building maintenance and purchasing equipment.  That means schools will be allowed to buy iPads with the extra cash, but not pens and paper. And its been noted the money hes set aside for schools is tens of millions less than has been allocated to fix potholes. Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said that while the announcement was welcome, schools needed more. Shadow Education Secretary Angela Rayner added: It is utterly insulting to parents and teachers for the Chancellor to talk about little extra. School budgets have been cut by billions and head-teachers are begging parents for money for basic supplies like books and stationery.

story: NewsTory MP claims rich people get married and stay together while the poor do notMichael Tomlinson insisted more money should be spent on preventing family breakdownShareCommentsByRichard Wheeler:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe MP said more money should be spent preventing family breakdown "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRich people get married and stay together while poor people do not, a Conservative MP has claimed. Michael Tomlinson warned marriage appears to be disappearing in Government policy-making just as much as its disappearing in our poorest communities, as he contributed to the Budget debate in the Commons. He insisted more money should be spent on preventing family breakdown, saying that in turn it would mean lower amounts are spent on dealing with the consequences. Speaking in the Commons, Mr Tomlinson said: Im very grateful to the work of the Centre for Social Justice and the work they do in this area because its from the CSJ that I learnt that despite the increased poverty risks, its estimated that the Treasury spends about pound in preventative spending for every pound, responding to the consequences of family breakdown. Further, itd appear that marriage is disappearing in policy-making - just as much as its disappearing in our poorest communities.  Because % of high-earners marry, % of low-earners marry - the rich get married and stay together, the poor dont. Why does this matter  Because where there is poverty, family breakdown is often not far behind - and while poverty is often a driver of family breakdown, crucially so too is family breakdown a driver of poverty. According to the Department for Work and Pensions, children who experience family breakdown are twice as likely to fall into poverty.Listen to our Ayes to the Left Podcast: Budget treat or trickery  And despite the chuntering from the benches opposite, the public really do get this - recent CSJ polling confirmed that young people aged  to  aspire to a lasting a relationship, just as much and they find that just as important as they aspire to a long-term career. Its clear support to the family is important for social mobility and its also important for alleviating poverty. Marriage and the family should not be disappearing from Government policy-making. When it comes to the Budget and our public services, it seems to me that more can be spent on prevention and this would mean less is spent on the consequences of family breakdown.

title: american schoolgirl flies uk honour
story: NewsAmerican schoolgirl flies to UK to honour great-great grandads bravery which saw him awarded Victoria Cross in World War OneEight-year-old Clara Levacy visited to honour Harry Greenwood, who is one of the most decorated men in British military historyShareCommentsByMichael Greenwood:,  OCT NewsClara Levacy, , travelled to the UK to honour her great-great grandfather Harry Greenwood VC"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLast week, an eight-year-old girl from San Diego, Calornia, left the United States for the first time in her le to travel to shyWindsor in Berkshire. She had been given special permission by her teacher to be absent and she has to write a journal for her class. And it is going to be quite a story. Clara Levacy had travelled with her family to honour her great-great-grandfather, who is one of the most decorated men in British military history. A hundred years ago on Tuesday, October , Harry Greenwood was fighting in the Battle of the Selle, in France, and was awarded the Victoria Cross for a series of acts of gallantry that many people have said mark him out as a “lunatic”.  Lieutenant Colonel Greenwood was leading the th Battalion of the King’s Own Yorkshire Light Infantry on October ,  in a fierce battle against a battered but determined German army. Many of his men had been killed by a machine gun. Harry got up and, with bullets flying all around him, ran towards the gun post and killed the crew with grenades. Later that day, he again rushed a gun in the same way before leading his men to capture  prisoners and eight machine guns. The following morning he again ran towards Germans firing a machine gun. As the citation for his Victoria Cross put it: “He showed the greatest gallantry ... in the face of heavy fire. His valour was beyond all praise.” Harry is my great-great-uncle and I’ve read a letter in which he says he enjoyed “killing Bosche”. That’s a frightening and incomprehensible thing to read about someone who shares a signicant amount of your DNA. But now that I have read about how he handled himself in the trenches and how he fought so bravely to protect the men with him, I am shyincredibly proud.  Prior to being awarded the VC he had got the MCfor gallantry in  and in July  a DSOfor bravery under fire. In December,  it was announced he was also being awarded a “Bar” to add to his DSO for an occasion when he had fought off two enemy attacks – even after he had been blown up by a shell. As a Lt Col, Harry was one of the most senior ranks in the field – he did not have to stick his head above the trenches or run in front of his men. He could send “boys”, cannon fodder, to do the risky stuff. But not Harry. He ran with his men and ran from the front, and fought with them to protect them as best he could. He had been at war for four years, blown up by shells including friendly fire, been gassed and watched hundreds of his friends killed.  Shortly after the announcement of his VC, Harry wrote: “I did nothing really, save drive on, kill a few huns and cheer our own fellows on a bit when they flagged.” Harry’s brother, David, explained to family that Harry “lacked imagination” – while most people in combat worried about what would happen to themthey ran in front of firing machine guns, Harry was somehow able to block that out of his mind.  He was given his medal by King George V at Buckingham Palace in  and the Daily Mirror published his picture with that of four others awarded the VC that day. The following year he was part of the guard of honour when the Unknown Warrior was laid to rest at Westminster Abbey. In , Harry’s family donated his medals to the Regimental Museum of the King’s Own Yorkshire Light Infantry in Doncaster. In , the Government announced that every VC winner from the First World War born in the UK would be honoured with a paving stone laid in the town of their birth. So that is why I was joined last week by my rd cousin Clara Levacy and  other relatives from the extended Greenwood family in Windsor to mark the shycentenary of Harry’s actions.  If anyone there was in doubt of the signicance of Harry’s achievements, Colonel Dan Reeve of The Rlesspoke to say: “Hiswas an exceptional le that showed a pattern of selfless behaviour in which he routinely placed the interests of others before that of his own.  “He understood that a successful le was not one that pursued self-gratication, but rather one that sought to serve others and build society.” As we watched that paving stone being unveiled by a representative of The Queen and listened as a bugler from The Rles Regiment played Last Post, I read out the names of the  men from Harry’s battalion who died in the two days for which he was awarded the VC.  Among them was the name Harry Greenwood – when I first read it I thought it was a mistake but then I checked. By sad coincidence, on the day one Harry Greenwood got the VC, another Harry Greenwood from the same battalion was killed in action. Private Harry Greenwood was the son of a musician from Wombwell, nearly Barnsley – and he was just . We remembered him as we remembered our Harry. Band of Four Fighting Brothers

NewsThe disorder can cause temper tantrums and dramatic changes in a childs behaviour "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailParents have spoken about the horrying effects a simple bug has had on their children - turning them into angry strangers, with nervous tics and anxiety. Little-known condition Paediatric autoimmune neuropsychiatric disorder , affects one in every  children and can be treated with a simple course of antibiotics. The disorder occurs when the streptococcus group of bacteria, a common cause of sore or ‘strep’ throat, flares up, triggering an immune response which inflames part of the brain called the basal ganglia. This affects a persons control of their behaviour and emotions. But the strange behavioural changes the disorder causes in a child can often be mistaken for mental health issues, meaning many children go years without getting a proper diagnosis. Evie Prior was four when she was diagnosed with Pandas, leading to fiery temper tantrums, extreme separation anxiety and even saw her wetting herself up to three times a day.  Tragically, Evie suffered for four years before receiving a diagnosis, reports Mail Online. Evies mum Helen said: Overnight, Evie became a dferent child. She also started to develop bizarre sensory issues, including not being able to find the perfect feeling sicks every morning. Helen added: We’d go through six or seven pairs every morning because she could never find any that felt right. Over time, Evie also began obsessing with using the toilet. Her mum added: Suddenly I had a six-year-old who was obsessed with going to the toilet. It had to be the very last thing she did before she left the house. Helen, , said le soon revolved around her daughters obsessive trips to the loo, where she would spend half an hour at a time, crying and distressed because she was convinced she hadn’t finished.  She just couldn’t get off. She became terried of going anywhere, says Helen. Evie was eventually put on a course of antibiotics, with a GP suspecting she was suffering from a urinary tract infection. When Evies behaviour ed to normal, the family were relieved to have their little girl back - before the odd behaviour started once again when her antibiotics ended. With Evie often complaining of a sore throat, mum Helen began researching online and found a blog written by an American mother whose child had been diagnosed with Pandas. After years of fighting for the diagnosis, Evie, now , was eventually diagnosed  months ago by a US specialist her mother consulted via Skype. She has now been on antibiotics continuously for the past year and has had two courses of high-dose steroids.  Georgia Tuckey, an NHS nurse who co-founded the charity Pans Pandas UK earlier this year, also experienced something similar when her -year-old son fell ill in . She resorted to travelling to the America in  for treatment - having to sell the family home to pay for it. Georgia told Good Health: I understand the challenges parents face. I’m a nurse, but I still couldn’t get anyone to believe me. It’s a huge struggle because to many doctors the symptoms look like other conditions for which there are already treatment guidelines.

title: meghan markle cant keep hands
story: NewsWhy Meghan Markle cant keep her hands off her little baby bump - according to a midweThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex are expecting their first child in the Spring of ShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsMeghan Markle cant keep her hands off her baby bump "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNews broke of Meghan Markles pregnancy on the first day of her royal tour overseas with husband Prince Harry. The royal couple arrived in Australia glowing and ever since that moment the public have been keeping a keen eye on Meghans growing bump. People have showered the parents-to-be with gts for their unborn child and taken delight at hearing Harry, , open up about becoming a parent and discussing their little bump. Hes also recently revealed whether hes hoping to have a boy or a girl.  But more than this theres one thing thats really captured the attention of royal fans -the fact that no matter where she is, the Duchess simply cant stop touching and cradling her stomach. We think its totally adorable, but we cant help wondering why shes doing it  Thankfully a midwe has shared the answer. Lesley Gilchrist co-founder of My Expert Midwe explained to MailOnline that its a perfectly natural impulse no matter the size of the bump, to instinctively protect her unborn baby.  She revealed that an expectant mother may touch their bump anytime as they navigate the changes in the body and experience new sensations. Although most women will start to feel their baby move by around - weeks, some women may feel this sooner, says Lesley. Flutterings are the first sensations that are felt. However gas movement through the gut feels similar and this may cause an instinctive, involuntary touching of the stomach. It’s not uncommon for women at a similar stage to the Duchess of Sussex to feel those sensations.  She added: Those feelings of your baby moving are extremely special for women. It is such an amazing time. However not everyone is aware of this, and many people on social media have branded Meghans actions staged. One Twitter user wrote: Im not sureits a natural thing to do when pregnant or whether its a little bit staged. story: NewsParents shock after Universal Credit leaves them with just p to live onThe panic-stricken parents Melissa Whitchurch and Chris Steer say they were told it was "their problem" by the Department for Work and PensionsShareCommentsByLaura Sharman:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics article.ece,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family-of-three were expected to survive with less than a pound in their bank account for a week after a mistake over their benefits. In a panic, Melissa Whitchurch, , called the Department for Work and Pensions hotline but claim she was that it was her problem. Melissa and her partner Chris Steer were expecting a Universal Credit payment of pound to be paid into their bank account at midnight last Thursday and had budgeted accordingly. However, to the mum-of-ones horror, when she went to draw out the money, her balance was just  pence. Melissa claimed the officer said the payment was not due for another six days and, when she tried to explain the mistake, told her it was her problem and hung up.  The couple resorted to scouring their home to find things they could potentially sell so they could afford to feed their three-year-old daughter, Cheyanne. Melissa, from Brighton, East Sussex, said: All that was going through my mind was how am I going to feed my daughter and send her to school without her snacks  The children all put healthy food in a box at school in the morning, such as fruit and crackers, and then they sit down and eat it together during story time. It breaks my heart to think of her feeling like the odd one out, sat there watching everybody  eat their fruit when she doesnt have any. Melissa had originally asked the DWP to change her payment schedule from a monthly arrangement to a fortnightly one. Cheyenne is really sweet about it and she doesnt really understand, thank goodness. We try to keep her away from it. But when she sees Im upset, she will come over and cuddle me and say its okay mummy. Its horrible and the people that are supposed to help just dont care. They are heartless.  The family have been surviving on food donations from strangers and neighbours who heard about their desperate situation. Have you been affected by Universal Credit  Email webnews@mirror  Melissa said: I could have gone to the food bank last week but since I thought I would be paid the next day, I didnt and the next one isnt for another week. So weve been getting by thanks to the kindness of other people. One lady heard about my situation and came and gave us some bread, milk, ham and cheese and Id never even seen or spoken to her before.  Melissa said she would love nothing more than toto work since she was signed off due to problems with her health  years ago. But the former shop assistant has limited mobility and has aids to help her around the house due to her back pain and other health issues, for which she takes more than  tablets per day.  Chris was also signed off from his job as a chef just five months ago for mental health reasons. Universal Credit is a new benefits system, introduced to simply and replace many existing benefits and tax credits and consists of a single, monthly benefit payment into a bank account. Under UC, evidence shows people are moving into work faster and staying in work longer.The Mirror is urging our readers to back our petition to stop the rollout Universal Credit which is plunging families into debt and despair and replace it with a fair system.

Hurricane Oscar is barrelling across the Atlantic and could hit the UK at the same time as a separate low pressure system bringing stormy conditions over the weekend.If the low system hits on its own, it could become Storm Deirdre, which is the next named storm on the list. story: News"Your n***** kid is not welcome": Pensioner arrested after horric racist letter sent to new neighbourDeborah Cantwell has been charged with intimidation and criminal mischief after she allegedly targeted a -year-old mixed race boyShareByHana Carter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsCantwell allegedly covered the familys property in toilet paper "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family were horried after being sent a racist note saying: no n*****s wanted in this neighbourhood when they moved into their new home. story: NewsPregnant woman mortied after being shamed by fitness instructor and kicked out of exercise classAn expectant mother claims she was asked to leave an exercise class simply because shes pregnantShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  OCT NewsNatalie Hillar says she was shamed by a fitness instructor for being pregnant "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen going through a pregnancy, all sorts of changes occur in the body and everyone has their own way of dealing with this.Some abruptly stop going about their daily routine during this time and adapt an incredibly dferent lestyle to ensure there are no complications - but others continue on as they were before. One mum-to-be has been attempting to maintain her fitness levels after finding out shes going to have a child, but it seems not everyone thinks she should be doing this. Natalie Hillar from Sydney, Australia, claims she was recently forced to leave a gym class by an instructor who shamed her for being pregnant.  The communications consultant who is six months pregnant said she felt humiliated by this incidnet. According to the mother-of-two, last Wednesday she attended her regular Bodycombat session at a local Fitness First gym. Speaking to Daily Mail Australia, the -year-old said: I went to the class as ususal. I took a position at the back of the room and the instructor read out the disclaimer which they do in every class. She warnedanyone has any pregnancies or injuries to make sure they have a medical clearance, which I confidently have.  Natalie goes on to explain how the class starts and she follows the moves at a comfortable pace, avoiding jumping around. Then suddenly the instructor shuts off the music and reportedly says: I dont knowanyone heard me at the beginning of the class but I dont teach this class to pregnant people. Unsureshed heard her properly, Natalie continued exercising. But the music soon stopped once again.  She claims the instructor repeated her earlier words: She stopped the music again and said I can still see pregnant people in this class, I refuse to teach pregnant people. At that point I realised I needed to leave, recalls Natalie.As I was walking out, I glared at her. Then she grabbed the microphone and shouted I know youre upset, but its for your own good, love. She added: I felt really humiliated. What confuses me most is Ive been to the same class for my previous pregnancies and I never had any problems.  A spokesman for Fitness First explained that the safety of members is their number one priority. They added: We understand the level of exercise during pregnancy is personal and usually determined by pre-pregnancy fitness levels and advice from general practitioners. In addition to advice from their GP, we recommend any pregnant members noty the group fitness instructor prior to participating in a class. All of our group exercise instructors are required to make members aware of any risks and recommend against exercises should they be unsafe. In this case, this was the professional recommendation given. The class BODYCOMBAT is not recommended during pregnancy because of the joint instability. They added that their team are currently in touch with Ms Hillar.

title: callum booth keen to keep feelgood factor going at dundee united
story: Callum Booth is delighted to see everyone associated with Dundee United pulling in the same direction and he’s determined to reward today’s travelling support with more to cheer at Dunfermline.The Tangerines head to East End Park today for new manager Robbie Neilson’s third match in charge.Despite only being in charge for a couple of weeks now, United left-back Booth says the new gaffer has already made quite an impression.He said: “It’s been brilliant, really good. Training has been really good and I thinkyou asked any of the boys in the changing-room we’d all be the same.“It’s really gone up a level, we’re all enjoying it and I think that shows on a Saturday.“It’s been quite tough but I think we needed that. It’s been enjoyable at the same time, though, and we’re all buying into his ideas.”Off the field there seems to be an air of optimism around Tannadice but Booth knows getting results on the pitch is the only way to realise their hopes of promotion.And that means keeping their unbeaten run under the new boss going against a Dunfermline side that have already bagged a deserved win over the Tangerines.Booth added: “Four points from the first two games isn’t too bad but I think they were two good performances as well.“We feel hard done by we didn’t get the win over Inverness – I think most people there would agree with that but it wasn’t to be.“At least we put in a really positive performance and everyone is pulling in the same direction.“There is a good feel about the place and, hopefully, we can kick on now and go on a little run.“The players, coaching staff, fans all seem to be pulling in the same direction especially since the new gaffer has come in.“A thousand fans down at Partick, great backing and then same again last weekend. The fans were right with us until the last minute.“It does help, it makes a massive dference and Dunfermline isn’t too far down the road so I’d expect another good away following.“I think the fans can see the work and effort we’re putting in, evenwe didn’t get the three points last Saturday.“The fans have been great and long may it continue.”Allan Johnston’s Pars have been struggling of late after a lightning fast start to the season saw them follow up four wins from four in the Betfred Cup group stage with an impressive - victory at Tannadice.Since then, Dunfermline have only managed eight points from the following eight games and were beaten - at home last weekend despite dominating against Queen of the South.In fact, scoring goals at home has been a real problem of late with just the two Championship strikes going in.Booth  Co., however, are wary of a repeat show from the Pars.He said: “Dunfermline were really good at Tannadice the first time we played them and thoroughly deserved to win.“I think most people would be surprised they’ve not kicked on from that first game.“They played well that day and deserved the win.“I’ve not seen much of them since but it’s not worked out for them since for whatever reason.“They’ll still be a dangerous opponent, though, because they are, obviously, capable of putting in a performance but have just been a bit inconsistent recently.“If we go about it like we have done in the last two games then we’ll give ourselves a chance.“We’ll be going there in positive spirits, try to take our chances and come back up the road with the three points.”

title: dundee appoint jimmy boyle as new assistant manager
story: Dundee have appointed Jimmy Boyle as assistant manager to Jim McIntyre.The -year-old steps up from his post as head of the Dark Blues youth academy to team up with the new boss who arrived to succeed Neil McCann last week.Jimmy has been in the dugout for the games against Livingston and Hearts and confirmation he’s to remain their permanently brings to an end the Billy Dodds saga that’s dragged on since the new manager arrived last week.Dodds, who was Jim’s number two at Ross County, was his first choice for the same post at Dens Park, but well documented matters relating to his departure after Dundee went into administration in  made him unacceptable to many Dark Blues fans.As well as him, it’s understood Dens legend Barry Smith and Aberdeen coach Barry Robson were also being considered.But Jim has opted for another man he knows well and who has extensive experience in coaching and management.The pair played together at Airdrie and during eight years with the Diamonds, Jimmy appeared in two Scottish Cup finals.After a career that included spells at a string of clubs including Queen’s Park, Livingston and Partick Thistle, he was Airdrie’s under- coach for several seasons before succeeding Kenny Black as manager in .He was sacked three years later, but was quickly appointed to the SFA’s coaching staff and in  was headhunted by Dundee to take charge of developing their emerging talent.Over the last two-and-half-years he’s transformed the fortunes of the club’s underage sides and last season saw him steer the Development squad to a second place finish in their league.Known for someone who prefers to stay out of the limelight, he has been persuaded to make the step back up to first team level and assist his old team-mate in keeping Dundee in the Premiership.A Dundee FC statement said: #Jimmy has been with the club since joining as head of youth development in . During that period he has overseen the academy while also managing the development side and helping out with the first team.

title: tom duthie neil mccann tried to change too much too soon at dundee
story: When Neil McCann looks back on his time as Dundee boss he will surely learn several lessons, ones that can stand him in good steadhe s to management.Perhaps the most obvious will be that, whatever your football philosophy, it has to be tapered to suit the resources you have available when it comes to players.McCann’s mantra at Dens was to play passing football at all times and, ultimately, at all costs. That led to too many goals being lost by errors as, at high risk, the ball was played out from the back.It became increasingly clear some of his defenders in particular were not comfortable with this policy but the manager was not for budging and persevered with the style of play he was convinced would, ultimately, bring success.The number of goals it cost made it inevitable what many saw as stubbornness was what cost McCann his job.That is, perhaps, an over-simplication and, now the dust has settled on the former Scotland international’s departure, a more in-depth look throws up other factors.A look at the players he used in his eight Premiership games in charge this term highlights another couple of causes for his downfall.First off, the list of those involved looks too long. In just two-and-a-half months of league football, Dundee fielded  dferent players.Of course, injury and suspension means some of the constant stream of changes were enforced, but others suggest he was never totally sure of what his best line-up was. Given the style of play he wanted, this lack of consistency in selection had to be an issue.Arguably, an even bigger one was that he fell into the rookie manager’s trap of trying to make too many changes too quickly.The Premiership may not be one of the top leagues in Europe but it does have its own unique qualities. One of them, as most new arrivals testy, is the tempo of the play here is more frantic than in many other countries.Even players coming up from England, where the pace is higher than on the continent, usually comment on that.What that means is players from where have to be given time to adjust and, as they do, it’s important they have men around them who are already experienced campaigners in our top ision.A glance down the list of the men used this season suggests there were not enough performers who fitted into that category.Of the  he used, nine were completely new to the league, while eight others had no more than a season’s experience of it.Ironically, the most used who fell into those categories was when  started the solitary win at Hamilton last month but, in the other outings, seven or eight such players were used.That’s not saying these players are not good enough for this level but, as most experienced managers in any league will say, whatever the level of talent, having so many who are not familiar with their surroundings is a risk they wouldn’t be prepared to take.While McCann did bring in vastly-experienced Premiership performer Kenny Miller at the end of the summer transfer window, the loss through injury of Paul McGowan had to be a major blow.And it should not be seen as insignicant that, as he’s scoured the free-agent market since his arrival as manager, new boss Jim McIntyre has paid particular attention to men who know the top flight well.Martin Woods is expected to sign up once he’s proved his fitness, though Celtic on Wednesday may be too early for that. Woods’ old Ross County team-mate from when McIntyre was in charge, Paul Quinn, has also been linked.

story: Members of the public have been advised to be wary of an influx of zombies in Inverness this weekend.The living dead are set to visit the Highland capital today and tomorrow as part of the cityrsquos annual Hallowersquoen celebrations.The ZombieNess celebrations will get under way with a "people hunt" tonight, with the zombies due to emerge from the Victorian Market at around pm.That will be followed by a second hunt tomorrow at pm.Organisers are still on the lookout for volunteers who are willing to be transformed into zombies, and all those who are keen to take part are asked to register between pm and .pm tonight or  noon and .pm tomorrow.Both of the hunts are expected to last two hours ndash unless the zombies prove adept at seeking out their prey.A mass zombie dance has been arranged for the immediate aftermath of tonightrsquos event.Participants will be asked to perform to Dead and Gone, a new track by rock group The Dead Daisies.The group are scheduled to headline the first-ever Monstersfest in Inverness on November  and , and the video for their latest track, which already features zombies, has been viewed around one million times on the video-sharing site YouTube.A film showing the Inverness zombies will be shown on both the bandrsquos and Highland Councilrsquos social media channels after the event.After tomorrowrsquos hunt, the focus will switch to Ness Islands, where the Hallowersquoen show will take place.The performance, Nights of the Living Dead, features young performers from across the Highlands, who have also designed many of the scenes in the show.It has been organised by a number of bodies, including Highland Council, Eden Court, Arts in Motion, Limelight Event Services and Fly Agaric.The show invites families to discover what is hiding behind the bushes at the ever-popular Inverness beauty spot.It will begin at .pm tomorrow and runs for approximately two hours, with a second performance scheduled for .pm on Sunday.Councillor Callum Smith, of the Inverness Events and Festivals working group, said: "We are really looking forward to welcoming families to this yearrsquos shows and we cannot wait to see all the children in their wonderful Halloween costumes."Every year it seems like more and more people are dressing up and helping us create something really unforgettable, and we cannot thank them enough for their support."A number of traffic restrictons will be in place as a result of the events, and motorists are asked to park well away from the site to ease congestion:Ness Walk closed northbound between Access for parking will be controlled by the event organiser.Bught Avenue closed to southbound traffic between its junction with Bught Lane and its junction with Bught Road. Northbound traffic will be maintained.Alternative routes are available using Bught Road , Bught Lane, Bught Drive, Bught Avenue, Glenurquhart Road, Bishoprsquos Road, Ness Walk , Balleary Lane and Balleary Road.Tuesday  Oct  : PM

title: Dilapidated factory site to be turned into homes
story: COUNCILLORS have welcomed news that a derelict factory and sawmill which can be seen by people using the new Holm Mills bridge is soon to be demolished.Tulloch Homesrsquo contractors are set to move in on Monday to begin the demolition of the eyesore which was built in  but has stood empty for many years.Tulloch will be taking it down as well as tidying up this area which was most recently used to store equipment while the bridge, part of the West Link, was being built.Inverness West councillor Alex Graham said he was delighted with the news."These are enormous unsightly buildings," he said. "The site is absolutely hideous and itrsquos in your face when you come off the bridge."Itrsquos a long-standing Inverness eyesore and as a resident who frequently uses the West Link, I very much welcome its removal at the earliest possible date."Irsquom sure thatrsquos a sentiment shared by everyone  in the city."Ness-side councillor Alasdair Christie echoed his council colleaguersquos views"Itrsquos in a very prominent site opposite the new roundabout just off the bridge," he said. "The buildings have been hidden from view for so long, but with the new bridge itrsquos a blight on the landscape."Itrsquos been derelict for years and obviously it becomes a danger because it could attract children on to the site. Itrsquos had industrial uses and I understand Tulloch have plans to build houses there."A Tulloch spokesman said the demolition work on the factory and adjacent buildings would be completed by Christmas."In the summer of  we will be preparing for the first phase of homes to be constructed for our Ness Side development, with the first occupants entering their new homes in the autumn," he said."The first phase will comprise a mix of executive and three and four bedroom homes, with access from Dores Road."The development will make a major contribution towards meeting Highland Councilrsquos target to tackle the cityrsquos housing need."Tulloch Homes have approval to build  homes at Ness Side over the next  to  years, after planning consent was granted by Highland Council last December. The spokesman added: "Ness Side will signicantly replenish our land bank in the city to ensure we can meet local demand for some time to come."Tuesday  Oct  : PM

title: Family raise cash for autism centre
story: An Inverness family has raised hundreds of pounds for a local autism support facility.Danielle McLeishrsquos son Connorwas diagnosed with the condition earlier this year.Since then she has been fundraising with the help of her family and friends to raise money for the Pines Centre at Drummond School, which supported little Connor.Miss McLeish and her daughter Christina Rosetook part in the Unicorn Pageant, supported by clothing firm Rogue Attitude.The family also organised a medium night at the Chieftain Hotel.In total they raised pound., and donated the sum to the centre along with a number of items to be raffled off."Drummond have been raising money for playground equipment as well as the library so part of the money will go towards that," Miss McLeish said."We also donated a few items to them as well for a raffle, which will hopefully raise even more."The textile company I work for sent me a load of throw blankets and things like that so they will go into the raffle as well."Pines will get some raffle prizes as well as the cheque."My mum and my brother came along as well. It was great that they were able to come along hey have been a great support for Connor."I donrsquot knowpeople realise the effect autism has on a family as a whole. Itrsquos good for people to be educated, and itrsquos good for us to be able to help in some small way."Now the family are planning to make their fundraising drive an annual event, and they have already had backing from local businesses.Miss McLeish insisted that the whole family are determined to do their bit to support the organisations which continue to support Connor."We have decided to make our fundraiser an annual thing," she added."The Chieftain Hotel have said we can use theirroom whenever we like for our next event which is brilliant."We definitely want to match what wersquove raised this year, andpossible, make it even bigger and better."Tuesday  Oct  : PM

title: Fans shocked by city folk gig walkout
story: Music lovers at an Inverness folk night were left stunned when two people walked out in the middle of a performance.Hamish MacDonald, the first person to be appointed as Scotlandrsquos national scriever, or writer in the Scots language, was performing a song he had penned about US President Donald Trump at Inverness Acoustic and Folk Clubrsquos second meeting.The less-than-complimentary lyrics prompted two American tourists to leave MacGregorrsquos bar in Academy Street, where the performance was taking place.The folk nightrsquos organiser, Jo de Sylva, said: "As is the way in folk music, Hamishrsquos performance did court controversy. He had written a song about Donald Trump, which was very, very funny."It was his third song out of six, and the main act hadnrsquot even come on at that point."Most of the crowd were really enjoying themselves and getting behind Hamish, but this couple just grabbed their jackets and stormed out."It turned out they were American and they had been offended by the song."Itrsquos a shame because folk music is historically about getting people to talk about these things."Miss de Sylva said other members of the audience were left perplexed by the incident, and insisted that type of song is not unusual in folk clubs."Itrsquos exactly the kind of thing you would expect to hear in a folk club. The music is traditionally left-leaning," she said."You need to understand that when you go to a folk club, not everyone there is going to agree with your views."People were a bit taken aback."I waited until the end of the song and tried to go after them but they had already gone."It was very unexpected."Despite the interruption, the rest of the event ran smoothly, and tickets are already selling fast for the clubrsquos next meeting."Apart from that, the night was amazing," Miss de Sylva added."It was exactly what you want a folk night to be like."It was only the second event we had held but it is going so well."There are only six tickets left for the next event, and they have only just gone on sale."Itrsquos gone way beyond what we expected it would be."Tuesday  Oct  : PM
